speaker: RADDATZ
text: Good evening to you all.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The rules for tonight are very basic and have been agreed to by all three campaigns in advance.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Candidates can take up to a minute-and-a-half to respond directly to a question.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: For a rebuttal, for a follow-up, 45 seconds will be allowed.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: There are green, yellow, and red lights that each candidate will see to signal when time is running out and when they're supposed to be finished with their answers.

speaker: MUIR
text: We will be tackling many critical issues right here tonight, and we begin with opening statements, in alphabetical order, and Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I'm delighted to be here in New Hampshire for this debate.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, the American president has to both keep our families safe and make the economy grow in a way that helps everyone, not just those at the top.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's the job.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have a strategy to combat and defeat ISIS without getting us involved in another ground war, and I have plans to raise incomes and deal with a lot of the problems that keep families up at night.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm very clear that we have a distinct difference between those of us on this stage tonight and all of our Republican counterparts.

speaker: CLINTON
text: From my perspective, we have to prevent the Republicans from rolling back the progress that we've made.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They would repeal the Affordable Care Act, not improve it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They would give more tax breaks to the super-wealthy and corporations, not to the middle class.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And they would, despite all their tough talk about terrorism, continue to let people who are on the no-fly list buy guns.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we have a lot of work to do in this campaign to make it clear where we stand in the Democratic Party, what we will do for our country, and I look forward to this evening's discussion of real issues that face the American people.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Thank you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Governor O'Malley?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Martha, thank you.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Tonight we have a different debate than the debates that we have been allowed to have so far, because tonight is different because of this reason, that in the course of this presidential campaign America has again been attacked by jihadi terrorists, American lives taken from us.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: So, yes, we must talk about our ideas to move our economy forward, but the first job of the president of the United States is to protect the people of the United States.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I visited with a number of our neighbors in Northern Virginia at a mosque last Friday.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And as I looked out there at the eyes of our neighbors, I also looked in the eyes of veterans.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I looked into the eyes of Boy Scouts.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I looked into the eyes of moms and dads who would do anything in their power to protect our country's values and our freedoms.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: What our nation needs right now is to realize that, while we face a terrible danger, we also face a different sort of political danger.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And that is the danger that democracies find themselves susceptible to when unscrupulous leaders try to turn us upon each other.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: What our country needs right now is new leadership that will bring us together around the values that unite us and the freedoms that we share as Americans.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We will rise to challenge of ISIL and we will rise together to the challenges that we face in our economy.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But we will only do so if we hold true to the values and the freedoms that unite us, which means we must never surrender them to terrorists, must never surrender our Americans values to racist, must never surrender to the fascist pleas of billionaires with big mouths.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We are a better country than this.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Our enduring symbol is not the barbed wire fence, it is the Statue of Liberty.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And America's best days are in front of us if we move forward together.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Good evening.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I am running for president of the United States because it is too late for establishment politics and establishment economics.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'm running for president because our economy is rigged because working people are working longer hours for lower wages and almost all of new wealth and income being created is going to the top one percent.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'm running for president because I'm going to create an economy that works for working families not just billionaires.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'm running for president because we have a campaign finance system which is corrupt, where billionaires are spending hundreds of millionaires of dollars to buy candidates who will represent their interests rather than the middle class and working families.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'm running because we need to address the planetary crisis of climate change and take on the fossil fuel industry and transform our energy system away from fossil fuel to energy efficiency and sustainable energy.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'm running for president because I want a new foreign policy; one that takes on Isis, one that destroys ISIS, but one that does not get us involved in perpetual warfare in the quagmire of the Middle East but rather works around a major coalition of wealthy and powerful nations supporting Muslim troops on the ground.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's the kind of coalition we need and that's the kind of coalition I will put together.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders thank you and thank you all.

speaker: MUIR
text: We do have a lot of important issues to get here tonight and we want to address the controversy of the last 24 hours right off the top because we heard some of the most heated rhetoric of the campaign so far between two of the campaigns on this stage tonight.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders, you fired a campaign staffer you have sued the Democratic National Committee; all of this after your campaign acknowledge that some of your staffers quote, "irresponsibly accessed data from another campaign."

speaker: MUIR
text: The Clinton campaign called this a very egregious breech of data of ethics and said, quote, "our data was stolen."

speaker: MUIR
text: Did they overstate this or were your staffers essentially stealing part of the Clinton playbook?

speaker: SANDERS
text: David, let me give you a little bit of background here.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The DNC has hired vendors.

speaker: SANDERS
text: On two occasions, there were breeches in information two months ago.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Our staff found information on our computers from the Clinton campaign.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And when our staffers said, "whoa, what's going here?"

speaker: SANDERS
text: They went to the DNC quietly.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They went to the vendor and said, "hey, something is wrong," and that was quietly dealt with.

speaker: SANDERS
text: None of that information was looked at.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Our staffer at that point did exactly the right thing.

speaker: SANDERS
text: A few days ago a similar incident happened.

speaker: SANDERS
text: There was a breach because the DNC vendor screwed up, information came to our campaign.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In this case, our staff did the wrong thing -- they looked a that information.

speaker: SANDERS
text: As soon as we learned that they looked at that information - we fired that person.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We are now doing an independent internal investigation to see who else was involved.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Thirdly, what I have a really problem, and as you mentioned - this is a problem, I recognize it as a problem.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But what the DNC did arbitrarily without discussing it with us is shut off our access to our information crippling our campaign.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is an egregious act.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'm glad that late last night, that was resolved.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Fourthly, I work -- look forward to working with Secretary Clinton for an investigation, an independent investigation, about all of the breaches that have occurred from day one in this campaign, because I am not convinced that information from our campaign may not have ended up in her campaign.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Don't know that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But we need an independent investigation, and I hope Secretary Clinton will agree with me for the need of that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Last point.

speaker: SANDERS
text: When we saw the breach two months, we didn't go running to the media and make a big deal about it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And it bothers me very much that, rather than working on this issue to resolve it, it has become many press releases from the Clinton campaign later.

speaker: MUIR
text: But Senator, you do mention the DNC -- the vender.

speaker: MUIR
text: But you said of your staff that they did the wrong thing.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Absolutely.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Bernie Sanders apologizes to Hillary Clinton

speaker: SANDERS
text: At ABC's Democratic presidential debate, candidate Bernie Sanders apologizes to rival Hillary Clinton for a scandal involving key voter data.

speaker: MUIR
text: So, does Secretary Clinton deserve an apology tonight?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes, I apologize.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Not only -- not only do I apologize to Secretary Clinton -- and I hope we can work together on an independent investigation from day one -- I want to apologize to my supporters.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This is not the type of campaign that we run.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And if I find anybody else involved in this, they will also be fired.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton, he has apologized.

speaker: MUIR
text: How do your react?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I very much appreciate that comment, Bernie.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It really is important that we go forward on this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know that you now have your data back, and that there has been an agreement for an independent inquiry into what did happen.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, we were distressed when we learned of it, because we have worked very hard -- I said in the beginning of this campaign, we want to reach as many voters as possible, and we have tens of thousands of volunteers doing that, and entering data all the time to keep up with what people are telling us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so, now that, I think, you know, we have resolved your data, we have agreed on an independent inquiry, we should move on.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because I don't think the American people are all that interested in this.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think they're more interested in what we have to say about all the big issues facing us.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Yeah, David, look, for crying out loud, our country has been attacked, we have pressing issues involving how we're going to adapt to this changing era of warfare.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Our economy -- people are working harder and being left behind.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: You want to know why things don't get done in Washington?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Because for the last 24 hours, with those issues being so urgent to people as they tune in tonight, wondering how they're even be able to buy presents for their kids.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Instead, we're listening to the bickering back and forth.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Maybe that is normal politics in Washington, but that is not the politics of higher purpose that people expect from our party.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need to address our security issues, we need to address the economic issues around the kitchen table.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And if people want a more high-minded politics and want to move our country forward, go on to martinomalley.com and help my campaign move our country forward.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: All three candidates are weighing in.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me agree with Governor O'Malley and let me agree with Secretary Clinton.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You know, we had this incident before, Secretary, with your famous e-mails.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Right?

speaker: SANDERS
text: And what I said and I think what Governor O'Malley is saying, and I hope you say, is when the middle class of this country is disappearing, when we have massive income and wealth inequality, when we're the only major country on earth not guaranteeing health care to all people, all the issues that the governor talked about, the secretary talked about, those are the issues.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Media notwithstanding.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Those are the issues that the American people want discussed.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I hope those are the issues we'll discuss.

speaker: MUIR
text: Good let's move on -- Senator Sanders, let's move on right to some of those issues.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: It is just six days before Christmas, as we all know in this country.

speaker: MUIR
text: It's typically a joyful time, as it is this year, as well.

speaker: MUIR
text: But it's also an anxious time.

speaker: MUIR
text: President Obama has acknowledged that what we saw in San Bernardino was an act of terrorism.

speaker: MUIR
text: But we remember the president said, right before Thanksgiving, there is no known specific and credible intelligence indicating a plot on the homeland.

speaker: MUIR
text: We now know that this couple had assembled an arsenal.

speaker: MUIR
text: They were not on law enforcement's radar.

speaker: MUIR
text: They were completely undetected.

speaker: MUIR
text: So as we approach another holiday, with the president again saying, late this week, no credible threat, Secretary Clinton, how confident should the American people be, that there aren't others like that couple right now in the U.S. going undetected?

speaker: MUIR
text: And what would you do as president to find them?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, first, the most important job of being president is obviously to keep our country safe and to keep the families of America safe.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have a plan that I've put forward to go after ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Not to contain them, but to defeat them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it has three parts.

speaker: CLINTON
text: First, to go after them and deprive them of the territory they occupy now in both Syria and Iraq.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Secondly, to go after and dismantle their global network of terrorism.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And thirdly, to do more to keep us safe.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Under each of those three parts of my plan, I have very specific recommendations about what to do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, in the first, we do have to have a -- an American-led air campaign, we have to have Arab and Kurdish troops on the ground.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Secondly, we've got to go after everything from North Africa to South Asia and beyond.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And then, most importantly, here at home, I think there are three things that we have to get right.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have to do the best possible job of sharing intelligence and information.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That now includes the internet, because we have seen that ISIS is a very effective recruiter, propagandist and inciter and celebrator of violence.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That means we have to work more closely with our great tech companies.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They can't see the government as an adversary, we can't see them as obstructionists.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've got to figure out how we can do more to understand who is saying what and what they're planning.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we must work more closely with Muslim-American communities.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Just like Martin, I met with a group of Muslim-Americans this past week to hear from them about what they're doing to try to stop radicalization.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They will be our early warning signal.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's why we need to work with them, not demonize them, as the Republicans have been doing.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: David, I am the very first...

speaker: MUIR
text: (inaudible) thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: I am the very first post-9/11 mayor and the very first post-9/11 governor.

speaker: MUIR
text: I understand, from the ground up, that when attacks like San Bernardino happen, when attacks like the attacks of 9/11 happen, that when people call 911, the first people to show up are the local first responders.

speaker: MUIR
text: Many of the things Secretary Clinton said are absolutely true, but they underscore a lack of investment that we have, as a nation, failed to make over these last 15 years in intelligence gathering, intelligence analysis, intelligence sharing.

speaker: MUIR
text: Not only in theater, in Syria and Iraq and other places where we embalk (ph) ourselves in toppling dictators without having any idea what comes next, but here in the homeland, as we protect people from this threat of the lone wolves and these changing tactics and strategies.

speaker: MUIR
text: I believe that what's happened here is that the president had us on the right course, but it's a lack of battle tempo.

speaker: MUIR
text: We have to increase the battle tempo, we have to bring a modern way of getting things done and forcing the sharing of information and do a much better job of acting on it in order to prevent these sorts of attacks in the future.

speaker: MUIR
text: And we're going to break down these issues tonight, but I do want to go to Senator Sanders because the concern going into Christmas is significant, as you know.

speaker: MUIR
text: A new ABC News poll shows 77 percent of Americans have little or no confidence in the government's ability to prevent a lone wolf attack.

speaker: MUIR
text: How would you specifically find would-be terrorist who are going undetected?

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'm one of the 77 percent.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think this is a very difficult issue.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me agree with much of what the secretary and the governor have said.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me tell you what I think we have got to do.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think it's a two-pronged issue.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Number one, our goal is to crush and destroy ISIS.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What is the best way to do it?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, I think there are some differences of opinion here, perhaps between the secretary and myself.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I voted against the war in Iraq because I thought unilateral military action would not produce the results that were necessary and would lead to the kind of unraveling and instability that we saw in the Middle East.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I do not believe in unilateral American action.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I believe in action in which we put together a strong coalition of forces, major powers and the Muslim nations.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think one of the heroes in a real quagmire out there, in a dangerous and difficult world, one of the heroes who we should recognize in the Middle East is King Abdullah II of Jordan.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This small country has welcomed in many refugees.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And Abdullah said something recently, very important.

speaker: SANDERS
text: He said, "Yes, international terrorism is by definition an international issue, but it is primarily an issue of the Muslim nations who are fighting for the soul of Islam. We the Muslims should lead the effort on the ground."

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I believe he is absolutely right.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator, thank you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, in the wake of the San Bernardino attack, you all emphasized gun control.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But our latest poll shows that more Americans believe arming people, not stricter gun laws, is the best defense against terrorism.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Are they wrong?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I think you have to look at both the terrorism challenge that we face abroad and certainly at home and the role that guns play in delivering the violence that stalks us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Clearly, we have to have a very specific set of actions to take.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, when Senator Sanders talks about a coalition, I agree with him about that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've got to build a coalition abroad.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We also have to build a coalition at home.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Abroad, we need a coalition that is going to take on ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know how hard that is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know it isn't something you just hope people will do and I've worked on that...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, can we stick to gun control?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, I'm getting...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Are they wrong?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm getting to that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because I think if you only think about the coalition abroad you're missing the main point, which is we need a coalition here at home.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Guns, in and of themselves, in my opinion, will not make Americans safer.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We lose 33,000 people a year already to gun violence, arming more people to do what I think is not the appropriate response to terrorism.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think what is...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Is creating much deeper, closer relations and, yes, coalitions within our own country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The first line of defense against radicalization is in Muslim-American community.

speaker: CLINTON
text: People who we should be welcoming and working with.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I worry greatly that the rhetoric coming from the Republicans, particularly Donald Trump, is sending a message to Muslims here in the United States and literally around the world that there is a "clash of civilizations," that there is some kind of Western plot or even "war against Islam," which then I believe fans the flames of radicalization.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So guns have to be looked at as its own problem, but we also have to figure out how we're going to deal with the radicalization here in the United States.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Senator Sanders -- wait just a moment, please, Governor O'Malley.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Senator Sanders, we've seen those long lines of people buying guns in record numbers after the Paris attacks.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Would you discourage people from buying a gun?

speaker: SANDERS
text: It's a country in which people choose to buy guns.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think half of the -- more than half of the people in my own state of Vermont, my guess here in New Hampshire, are gun owners.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's the right of people.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But this is what I do believe.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I believe that when we have some 300 million guns in this country, I believe that when we have seen these horrific mass killings, not only in San Bernardino, but in Colorado and movie theaters in Colorado, I think we have got to bring together the vast majority of the people who do in fact believe in sensible gun safety regulations.

speaker: SANDERS
text: For example, talking about polls, a poll recently came out, overwhelming majority of the American people say we should strengthen the instant background check.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Who denies that it is crazy...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Who denies that it is crazy to allow people to own guns who are criminals or are mentally unstable?

speaker: SANDERS
text: We've got to eliminate the gun show loophole.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In my view, we have got to see that weapons designed by the military to kill people are not in the hands of civilians.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think there is a consensus.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think -- I'm not going to say that everybody is in agreement.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It's a divided country on guns.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But there is a broad consensus on sensible gun safety regulations that I, coming from a state that has virtually no gun control, will do my best to bring together.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Martha, if I may...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Senator Sanders.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I think we're going to go on...

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Excuse me, no.

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor, we have to abide the rules here, we'll call on you here shortly, but...

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I am the only person on this stage who has actually...

speaker: MUIR
text: But I do want pick up on something...

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: ... passed comprehensive gun safety legislation with a ban on combat assault weapons, David.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And, look, there are profound differences...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Senator Sanders voted against the Brady Bill.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Senator Sanders voted to give immunity to gun dealers.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And Senator Sanders voted against even research dollars to look into this public health issue.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Secretary Clinton changes her position on this every election year, it seems, having one position in 2000 and then campaigning against President Obama and saying we don't need federal standards.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Look, what we need on this issue is not more polls.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need more principle.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: When ISIL does training videos that say the easiest way to get a combat assault weapon in the United States of America is at a gun show, then we should all be waking up.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need comprehensive gun safety legislation and a ban on assault weapons.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Governor, now -- and let me stay with gun control for a minute, then.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You talk about assault weapons.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Even if you were able to ban the purchase of assault weapons tomorrow, Americans already own an estimated 7 to 10 million semi-automatic rifles.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Would you make it illegal to own those weapons, force people to turn them in?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And if not, how would banning the sales really make a difference?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Because, Martha, it would prevent people like the guy that just got charged yesterday perhaps from being able to buy combat assault weapons.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: You know, we are the only nation, only developed nation on the planet...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But, again, I'm not talking about buying.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Would you have them confiscated?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The ones that are already here?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: No, Martha, I would not.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And that's not what we did in Maryland.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But you know what we did in Maryland?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We overcame the NRA's objections.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We overcame all of the crowds that were coming down there.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We did our own rallies.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And at least if we enact these laws in a prospective way, we can address a major vulnerability in our country.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: ISIL videos, ISIL training videos are telling lone wolves the easiest way to buy a combat assault weapon in America is at a gun show.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And it's because of the flip-flopping, political approach of Washington that both of my two colleagues on this stage have represented there for the last forty years.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Whoa, whoa, whoa.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's calm down a little bit, Martin.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, let's tell the truth, Martin.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I am telling the truth.

speaker: SANDERS
text: First of all, let's have some rules here, commentators.

speaker: MUIR
text: We will.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SANDERS
text: All right.

speaker: MUIR
text: But let me just establish that for you, senator.

speaker: MUIR
text: Really quickly governor, we are going to call on you tonight and it's very clear you have a lot to say but please wait until you're called upon.

speaker: MUIR
text: And senator, he invoked your record and I'll let you respond.

speaker: SANDERS
text: He sure did.

speaker: MUIR
text: I'll let you respond.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He invoked mine as well.

speaker: MUIR
text: And you will get some to as well.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Sure did.

speaker: SANDERS
text: All right.

speaker: SANDERS
text: First off, we can do all the great speeches we want but you're not going to succeed unless there is a consensus.

speaker: SANDERS
text: In 1988, just to set the record straight governor, I ran for the U.S. House.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We have one House member from Vermont, three candidates in the race.

speaker: SANDERS
text: One candidate said, you know what, I don't think it's a great idea that we sell automatic weapons in this country that are used by the military to kill people very rapidly.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Gun people said, there were three candidates in the race, you vote for one of the others, but not Bernie Sanders.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I lost that election by three percentage points.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Quite likely, for that reason.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So please, do not explain to me, coming from a state where democratic governors and republican governors have supported virtually no gun control.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Excuse me.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Do not tell me that I have not shown courage in standing up to the gun people, in voting to ban assault weapons, voting for instant background checks, voting to end the gun show loop hole and now we're in a position to create a consensus in America on gun safety.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: I want to move on here.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton, you brought up Donald Trump a short time ago.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I do and this is an important issue and I know we'll get to a lot of other critical ones as well.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I actually agree with Governor O'Malley about the need for common sense gun safety measures.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I applaud his record in Maryland.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I just wish he wouldn't misrepresent mine.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have been for the Brady bill, I have been against assault weapons.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have voted not to give gun makers and sellers immunity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I also know that -- and I'm glad to see this -- Senator Sanders has really moved in face of the facts about what we're confronting in our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know that he has said in the two previous that he wants to take on this immunity issue because we need to send a strong message to the gun manufacturers, to the sellers, to the gun lobby.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I would hope, Senator Sanders, that you would join the Democrats who are trying to close the Charleston loophole, that you would sponsor or co-sponsor legislation to remove the absolute immunity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need to move on this consensus that exists in the country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's no longer enough just to say the vast majority of Americans want common sense gun safety measures including gun owners.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need, and only the three of us will do this, nobody on the Republican side will even admit there's a problem.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And in whatever way the three of us can we need to move this agenda forward and begin to deal with the gun lobby and the intimidation that they present.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: We're going to move on from guns here and go back to something you mentioned a short time ago.

speaker: MUIR
text: You brought up Donald Trump first here this evening.

speaker: MUIR
text: We've now seen the polling done well after his proposed ban on Muslims coming to America.

speaker: MUIR
text: Thirty-six percent of Americans, more than a third, agree with him.

speaker: MUIR
text: You have weighed in already on Donald Trump.

speaker: MUIR
text: You've weighed in on the proposed ban.

speaker: MUIR
text: But what would you say to the millions of Americans watching tonight who agree with him?

speaker: MUIR
text: Are they wrong?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well I think a lot of people are understandably reacting out of fear and anxiety about what they're seeing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: First what they saw in Paris, now what they have seen in San Bernardino.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And Mr. Trump has a great capacity to use bluster and bigotry to inflame people and to make think there are easy answers to very complex questions.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So what I would say is, number one, we need to be united against the threats that we face.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need to have everybody in our country focused on watching what happens and reporting it if it's suspicious, reporting what you hear.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Making sure that Muslim Americans don't feel left out or marginalized at the very moment when we need their help.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, I was a senator from New York after 9/11, and we spent countless hours trying to figure out how to protect the city and the state from perhaps additional attacks.

speaker: CLINTON
text: One of the best things that was done, and George W. Bush did this and I give him credit, was to reach out to Muslim Americans and say, we're in this together.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You are not our adversary, you are our partner.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we also need to make sure that the really discriminatory messages that Trump is sending around the world don't fall on receptive ears.

speaker: CLINTON
text: He is becoming ISIS's best recruiter.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They are going to people showing videos of Donald Trump insulting Islam and Muslims in order to recruit more radical jihadists.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I want to explain why this is not in America's interest to react with this kind of fear and respond to this sort of bigotry.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders, I did want to ask you about a neighbor in San Bernardino who reportedly witnessed packages being delivered to that couple's home, that it set off red flags, but they didn't report it because they were afraid to profile.

speaker: MUIR
text: What would you say to Americans afraid to profile?

speaker: MUIR
text: Is it ever acceptable?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, the answer is, obviously, if you see suspicious activity, you report it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's kind of a no-brainer.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You know, somebody is loading guns and ammunition into a house, I think it's a good idea to call 911.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Do it.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: MUIR
text: But I'm asking about -- I'm asking about profiling.

speaker: MUIR
text: Because a lot of people are afraid of that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But I want to talk -- I want to talk about something else, because Secretary Clinton I think made some interesting and good points.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What you have now is a very dangerous moment in American history.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The secretary is right: Our people are fearful.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They are anxious on a number of levels.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They are anxious about international terrorism and the possibility of another attack on America.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We all understand that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But you know what else they're anxious about?

speaker: SANDERS
text: They're anxious about the fact that they are working incredibly long hours, they're worried about their kids, and they're seeing all the new income and wealth -- virtually all of it -- going to the top 1 percent.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And they're looking around them, and they're looking at Washington, and they're saying the rich are getting much richer, I'm getting poorer, what are you going to do about it?

speaker: SANDERS
text: What are you going to do for my kids?

speaker: SANDERS
text: And somebody like a Trump comes along and says, "I know the answers. The answer is that all of the Mexicans, they're criminals and rapists, we've got to hate the Mexicans. Those are your enemies. We hate all the Muslims, because all of the Muslims are terrorists. We've got to hate the Muslims."

speaker: SANDERS
text: Meanwhile, the rich get richer.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So what I say to those people who go to Donald Trump's rallies, understand: He thinks a low minimum wage in America is a good idea.

speaker: SANDERS
text: He thinks low wages are a good idea.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I believe we stand together to address the real issues facing this country, not allow them to divide us by race or where we come from.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's create an America that works for all of us, not the handful on top.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator, thank you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I want to move to another...

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Martha, may I -- Martha, may I...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: No, no, not yet, Governor O'Malley.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Can I share this quick story?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: No, not yet, Governor O'Malley.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Oh.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: All right.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I'll come to you when we call on you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you very much.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: When you come back to me, I'll share that story.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You'll be happy.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I'll let -- I'll let you talk then.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, I want to talk about a new terrorist tool used in the Paris attacks, encryption.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: FBI Director James Comey says terrorists can hold secret communications which law enforcement cannot get to, even with a court order.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You've talked a lot about bringing tech leaders and government officials together, but Apple CEO Tim Cook said removing encryption tools from our products altogether would only hurt law-abiding citizens who rely on us to protect their data.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So would you force him to give law enforcement a key to encrypted technology by making it law?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would not want to go to that point.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would hope that, given the extraordinary capacities that the tech community has and the legitimate needs and questions from law enforcement, that there could be a Manhattan-like project, something that would bring the government and the tech communities together to see they're not adversaries, they've got to be partners.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It doesn't do anybody any good if terrorists can move toward encrypted communication that no law enforcement agency can break into before or after.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There must be some way.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't know enough about the technology, Martha, to be able to say what it is, but I have a lot of confidence in our tech experts.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And maybe the back door is the wrong door, and I understand what Apple and others are saying about that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I also understand, when a law enforcement official charged with the responsibility of preventing attacks -- to go back to our early questions, how do we prevent attacks -- well, if we can't know what someone is planning, we are going to have to rely on the neighbor or, you know, the member of the mosque or the teacher, somebody to see something.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I just think there's got to be a way, and I would hope that our tech companies would work with government to figure that out.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Otherwise, law enforcement is blind -- blind before, blind during, and, unfortunately, in many instances, blind after.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So we always have to balance liberty and security, privacy and safety, but I know that law enforcement needs the tools to keep us safe.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that's what i hope, there can be some understanding and cooperation to achieve.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And Governor O'Malley, where do you draw the line between national security and personal security?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I believe that we should never give up our privacy; never should give up our freedoms in exchange for a promise of security.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need to figure this out together.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need a collaborative approach.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need new leadership.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: The way that things work in the modern era is actually to gather people around the table and figure these things out.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: The federal government should have to get warrants.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: That's not some sort of passe you know, antique sort of principle that safeguards our freedoms.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But at the same time with new technologies I believe that the people creating these projects -- I mean these products also have an obligation to come together with law enforcement to figure these things out; true to our American principles and values.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: My friend Kashif, who is a doctor in Maryland; back to this issue of our danger as a democracy of turning against ourselves.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: He was putting his 10 and 12-year-old boys to bed the other night.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And he is a proud American Muslim.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And one of his little boys said to him, "Dad, what happens if Donald Trump wins and we have to move out of our homes?"

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: These are very, very real issues.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Ð¢his is a clear and present danger in our politics within.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need to speak to what unites us as a people; freedom of worship, freedom of religion, freedom of expression.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And we should never be convinced to give up those freedoms in exchange for a promise of greater security; especially from someone as untried and as incompetent as Donald Trump.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you, Governor O'Malley.

speaker: MUIR
text: Martha, we're going to turn now to refugees coming to America.

speaker: MUIR
text: And on the subject of refugees, more than half of all Americans now say they oppose taking in refugees from Syria and across the Middle East.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton, you have said that it would undermine who we are as Americans, shutting our doors.

speaker: MUIR
text: But New Hampshire's governor, where we are right here tonight, a democrat and a supporter of yours, is among more than 30 governors who are now concerned.

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor Maggie Hassan says, "we should halt acceptance of Syrian refugees until U.S. authorities can assure the vetting process, halt Syrian refugees."

speaker: MUIR
text: Is she wrong?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I agree that we have to have the toughest screening and vetting...

speaker: MUIR
text: But a halt?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I don't think a halt is necessary.

speaker: CLINTON
text: What we have to do is put all of our resources through the Department of Homeland Security, through the State Department, through our intelligence agencies, and we have to have an increased vetting and screening.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, this takes, David, 18 months to 24 months, two years.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I know it's not going to happen overnight and everything that can be done should be done.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But the process should move forward while we are also taking on ISIS, putting together the kind of strategy that I've advocated for, and making sure that the vetting and the screening is as tough as possible.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because I do believe that we have a history and a tradition, that is part of our values system and we don't want to sacrifice our values.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We don't want to make it seem as though we are turning into a nation of fear instead of a nation of resolve.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I want us to have a very tough screening process but I want that process to go forward.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And if at the end of 18 months, 24 months there are people who have been cleared, and I would prioritize widows, and orphans, and the elderly, people who may have relatives, families, or have nowhere else to go.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would prioritize them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that would I think give the American public a bit more of a sense of security about who is being processed and who might end up coming as refugees.

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor O'Malley, obviously you were governor yourself at one time.

speaker: MUIR
text: What would you say to New Hampshire's governor tonight?

speaker: MUIR
text: Is she wrong on this?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: No, what I would say is this is look, I was the first of the three of us to call for America to accept the 65,000 refugees we were asked to accept.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And if this humanitarian crisis increases, we should accept more.

speaker: MUIR
text: So the idea of a halt or a pause?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: David, there are wider vulnerabilities than when it comes to refugees.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I met recently with some members of the Chaldean Christian communities and the wait times are a year, 18 months, 24 months.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: There is a pretty excruciating process that refugees go through.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need to invest more in terms of the other sort of visas and the other sort of waivers.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: What these Chaldean families told me was that their families in Syria, when ISIS moves into their town, they actually paint a red cross across the door and mark their homes for demolition, and that tells the family you'd better get out now.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: The sort of genocide and brutality that the victims are suffering, these are not the perpetrators.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need to be the nation whose enduring symbol is the Statue of Liberty, and we need to act like the great country we are, according to our values.

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor, thank you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Senator Sanders -- Senator Sanders, we're going to move on.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're going to move on.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Excuse me.

speaker: SANDERS
text: May I have a chance to respond to this issue?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're going to move on to the fight against ISIS.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You're the one who told us we have to follow the rules and break it off.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yeah, but the rule includes equal -- got it.

speaker: SANDERS
text: All right.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: OK. Let's keep going.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you.

speaker: SANDERS
text: All right.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's keep going.

speaker: SANDERS
text: OK.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I do want to move to the fight against ISIS.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yeah.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: For the people of New Hampshire, the brutality of ISIS is personal.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: James Foley grew up here.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The first hostage, a journalist, brutally executed last year.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You've all said ISIS is a ruthless enemy and must be stopped.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Al Qaida as well.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Senator Sanders, you voted to send U.S. ground forces to fight in the coalition to help destroy Al Qaida in Afghanistan.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Can you then explain you why don't support sending U.S. combat troops to join a coalition to fight ISIS?

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I also voted and helped lead the effort against the war in Iraq, which will go down in history as one of the worst foreign blunders -- foreign policy blunders in the history of our country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I voted against the first Gulf War, which set the stage, I believe, for the second Iraq war.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And what I believe right now, and I believe this is terribly important, is the United States of America cannot succeed, or be thought of as the policeman of the world, that when there's an international crisis all over the world, in France and in the U.K. Or -- hey, just call up the American military and the American taxpayers, they're going to send the troops.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And if they have to be in the Middle East for 20 or 30 years no problem.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But why Al Qaida, why not ISIS?

speaker: SANDERS
text: I have a problem with that, Martha.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What I believe has got to happen is there must be an international coalition, including Russia, a well-coordinated effort.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But I agree, as I mentioned a moment ago, with King Abdullah.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This is a war for the soul of Islam.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The troops on the ground should not be American troops.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They should be Muslim troops.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I believe that countries like Saudi Arabia and Qatar have got to step up to the plate, have got to contribute the money that we need, and the troops that we need, to destroy ISIS with American support.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The administration has tried that over and over again.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: If it doesn't work and this threat is so great, what's your plan B?

speaker: SANDERS
text: My plan is to make it work, to tell Saudi Arabia that instead of going to war in Yemen, they, one of the wealthiest countries on Earth, are going to have to go to war against ISIS.

speaker: SANDERS
text: To tell Qatar, that instead of spending $200 billion on the World Cup, maybe they should pay attention to ISIS, which is at their doorstep.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, you too have ruled out a large U.S. combat force, yet you support sending in special operations forces to Syria, and sending those 100 to 200 troops to Iraq to do exploitation kill raids.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We've already lost one Delta Force member in a raid.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: It has looked very much to me like we're already in ground combat on frequent trips I've made there.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So, are you fooling Americans when you say, we're not putting American combat troops back into Syria or Iraq?

speaker: CLINTON
text: No.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Not at all.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that what we're facing with ISIS is especially complicated.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It was a different situation in Afghanistan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We were attacked from Afghanistan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Al Qaida was based in Afghanistan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We went after those who had attacked us.

speaker: CLINTON
text: What's happening in Syria and Iraq is that, because of the failures in the region, including the failure of the prior government in Baghdad, led by Maliki, there has been a resurgence of Sunni activities, as exemplified by ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we have to support Sunni-Arab and Kurdish forces against ISIS, because I believe it would be not only a strategic mistake for the United States to put ground combat troops in, as opposed to special operators, as opposed to trainers, because that is exactly what ISIS wants.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They've advertised that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They want American troops back in the Middle East.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They want American soldiers on the ground fighting them, giving them many more targets, and giving them a great recruiting opportunity.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, I think it's absolutely wrong policy for us to be even imagining we're going end up putting tens of thousands of American troops into Syria and Iraq to fight ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we do have to form a coalition.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know how hard that is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have formed them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I put together a coalition, including Arabs, with respect to Libya and a coalition to put sanctions onto Iran.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And you have to really work hard at it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the final thing I would say, bringing Donald Trump back into it, if you're going to put together a coalition in the region to take on the threat of ISIS you don't want to alienate the very countries and people you need to be part of the coalition.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so that is part of the reason why this is so difficult.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, I want -- I want to follow up on that.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You do support sending special operations forces there.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You support what the president has done already.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: One of the lessons people draw from Vietnam and war since is that a little force can turn into a little more and a little more.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: President Obama certainly didn't expect to be sending 30,000 additional troops into Afghanistan the first year of his presidency.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Are you prepared to run the risk of a bigger war to achieve your goals to destroy ISIS, or are you prepared to give up on those goals if it requires a larger force?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I just think you're asking a question with a false choice.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I believe if we lead an air coalition, which we are now in the position of doing and intensify it, if we continue to build back up the Iraqi army, which has had some recent success in Ramadi, as you know, if we get back talking to the tribal sheiks in Anbar to try to rebuild those relationships, which were very successful, in going after Al Qaida in Iraq, if we get the Turks to pay more attention to ISIS than they're paying to the Kurds, if we do put together the kind of coalition with the specific tasks that I am outlining, I think we can be successful in destroying ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So that's what I'm focused on, that's what I've outlined and that's what I would do as president.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Governor O'Malley.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You've emphasized the need for more human intelligence on the ground.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: What is it our intelligence community is not doing now that needs to be done?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Well, we have invested nowhere near what we should be investing in human intelligence on the ground.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And what I'm talking about is not only the covert CIA intelligence, I'm also talking about diplomatic intelligence.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I mean, we've seen time and time again, especially in this very troubled region of nation-state failures, and then we have no idea who the next generation of leaders are that are coming forward.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: So what I would say is not only do we need to be thinking in military terms, but we do our military a disservice when we don't greatly dial up the investment that we are making in diplomacy and human intelligence and when we fail to dial up properly, the role of sustainable development in all of this.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: As president, I would make the administrator of USAID an actual cabinet member.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We have to act in a much more whole of government approach, as General Dempsey said.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And I do believe, and I would disagree somewhat with one of my colleagues, this is a genocidal threat.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: They have now created a safe haven in the vacuum that we allowed to be partly and because of our blunders, to be created to be created in the areas of Syria and Iraq.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We cannot allow safe havens, and as a leader of moral nations around this Earth, we need to come up with new alliances and new ways to prepare for these new sorts of threats, because Martha, this will not be the last region where nation-states fail.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And you've seen a little bit of this emerging in the -- in the African Union and the things that they have done to better stabilize Somalia.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need to pay attention here in Central America as well.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: So this is the new type of threats that we're facing and we need to lead as a nation in confronting it and putting together new alliances and new coalitions.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I just want to quickly add...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Martha, that -- you know, one of the reasons why I have advocated for a no-fly zone is in order to create those safe refuges within Syria, to try to protect people on the ground both from Assad's forces, who are continuing to drop barrel bombs, and from ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And of course, it has to be de-conflicted with the Russians, who are also flying in that space.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm hoping that because of the very recent announcement of the agreement at the Security Council, which embodies actually an agreement that I negotiated back in Geneva in June of 2012, we're going to get a diplomatic effort in Syria to begin to try to make a transition.

speaker: CLINTON
text: A no-fly zone would prevent the outflow of refugees and give us a chance to have some safe spaces.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, I'd like to go back to that if I could.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: ISIS doesn't have aircraft, Al Qaida doesn't have aircraft.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: So would you shoot down a Syrian military aircraft or a Russian airplane?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I do not think it would come to that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are already de-conflicting air space.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We know...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But isn't that a decision you should make now, whether...

speaker: CLINTON
text: No, I don't think so.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I am advocating...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: ... if you're advocating this?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I am advocating the no-fly zone both because I think it would help us on the ground to protect Syrians; I'm also advocating it because I think it gives us some leverage in our conversations with Russia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now that Russia has joined us in the Security Council, has adopted an agreement that we hashed out a long day in Geneva three years ago, now I think we can have those conversations.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The no-fly zone, I would hope, would be also shared by Russia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: If they will begin to turn their military attention away from going after the adversaries of Assad toward ISIS and put the Assad future on the political and diplomatic track, where it belongs.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: MUIR
text: I want to take this to Senator -- I'm going to take this to Senator Sanders next, because I think there...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: SANDERS
text: I have a difference of opinion with Secretary Clinton on this.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Our differences are fairly deep on this issue.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We disagreed on the war in Iraq.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We both listened to the information from Bush and Cheney.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I voted against the war.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But I think -- and I say this with due respect -- that I worry too much that Secretary Clinton is too much into regime change and a little bit too aggressive without knowing what the unintended consequences might be.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes, we could get rid of Saddam Hussein, but that destabilized the entire region.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes, we could get rid of Gadhafi, a terrible dictator, but that created a vacuum for ISIS.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes, we could get rid of Assad tomorrow, but that would create another political vacuum that would benefit ISIS.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I think, yeah, regime change is easy, getting rid of dictators is easy.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But before you do that, you've got to think about what happens the day after.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And in my view, what we need to do is put together broad coalitions to understand that we're not going to have a political vacuum filled by terrorists, that, in fact, we are going to move steadily -- and maybe slowly -- toward democratic societies, in terms of Assad, a terrible dictator.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But I think in Syria the primary focus now must be on destroying ISIS and working over the years to get rid of Assad.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That's the secondary issue.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is exactly...

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator, thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is exactly what I just said and what I just described.

speaker: MUIR
text: Yeah, but, Secretary Clinton -- Secretary Clinton...

speaker: CLINTON
text: And that is important, because now we have a U.N. Security Council that will enable us to do that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, you know, with all due respect, Senator, you voted for regime change with respect to Libya.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You joined the Senate in voting to get rid of Gadhafi, and you asked that there be a Security Council validation of that with a resolution.

speaker: CLINTON
text: All of these are very difficult issues.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know that; I've been dealing with them for a long time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And, of course, we have to continue to do what is necessary when someone like Gadhafi, a despot with American blood on his hands, is overturned.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I'll tell you what would have happened, if we had not joined with our European partners and our Arab partners to assist the people in Libya, you would be looking at Syria.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now the Libyans are turning their attention to try to dislodge ISIS from its foothold and begin to try to move together to have a unified nation.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I was not the secretary of state...

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders, Senator Sanders, hold on.

speaker: MUIR
text: One moment, please.

speaker: MUIR
text: I'm going to ask the secretary here, because there does appear to be some daylight here between the policies, at least in respect to when you take out Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

speaker: MUIR
text: Right now or do you wait?

speaker: MUIR
text: Do you tackle ISIS first?

speaker: MUIR
text: You have said, Secretary Clinton, that you come to the conclusion that we have to proceed on both fronts at once.

speaker: MUIR
text: We heard from the senator just this week that we must put aside the issue of how quickly we get rid of Assad and come together with countries, including Russia and Iran, to destroy ISIS first.

speaker: MUIR
text: Is he wrong?

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think we're missing the point here.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We are doing both at the same time.

speaker: MUIR
text: But that's what he's saying, we should put that aside for now and go after ISIS.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I don't agree with that, because we will not get the support on the ground in Syria to dislodge ISIS if the fighters there who are not associated with ISIS, but whose principal goal is getting rid of Assad, don't believe there is a political, diplomatic channel that is ongoing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We now have that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have the U.N. Security Council adopting a resolution that lays out a transition path.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's very important we operate on both at the same time.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And let me just say a word about coalition-building, because I've heard Senator Sanders say this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know how hard it is to build coalitions.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think it would be a grave mistake to ask for any more Iranian troops inside Syria.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is like asking the arsonist to come and pour more gas on the fire.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The Iranians getting more of a presence in Syria, linking with Hezbollah, their proxy in Lebanon, would threaten Israel and would make it more difficult for us to move on a path to have a transition that at some point would deal with Assad's future.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: SANDERS
text: I happen to think...

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I'd like to offer a...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: She says we have to proceed on both fronts at once.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Secretary Clinton is right.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This is a complicated issue.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I don't think anyone has a magical solution.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But this is what I do believe.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes, of course Assad is a terrible dictator.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But I think we have got to get our foreign policies and priorities right.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The immediate -- it is not Assad who is attacking the United States.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is ISIS.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And ISIS is attacking France and attacking Russian airliners.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The major priority, right now, in terms of our foreign and military policy should be the destruction of ISIS.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I think -- and I think we bring together that broad coalition, including Russia, to help us destroy ISIS.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And work on a timetable to get rid of Assad, hopefully through Democratic elections.

speaker: SANDERS
text: First priority, destroy ISIS.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator sanders, thank you.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: May I offer a different generation's perspective on this?

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor O'Malley?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: During the Cold War -- during the Cold War, we got into a bad habit of always looking to see who was wearing the jersey of the communists, and who was wearing the U.S. jersey.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We got into a bad habit of creating big bureaucracies, old methodologies, to undermine regimes that were not friendly to the United States.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Look what we did in Iran with Mosaddegh.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And look at the results that we're still dealing with because of that.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I would suggest to you that we need to leave the Cold War behind us, and we need to put together new alliances and new approaches to dealing with this, and we need to restrain ourselves.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I mean, I know Secretary Clinton was gleeful when Gadhafi was torn apart.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And the world, no doubt is a better place without him.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But look, we didn't know what was happening next.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And we fell into the same trap with Assad, saying -- as if it's our job to say, Assad must go.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We have a role to play in this world.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But we need to leave the Cold War and that sort of antiquated thinking behind.

speaker: MUIR
text: But -- you criticized -- you criticized Secretary Clinton for what came next.

speaker: MUIR
text: What's your proposal for what comes after Assad?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I believe that we need to focus on destroying ISIL.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: That is the clear and present danger.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And I believe that we can springboard off of this new U.N. resolution, and we should create, as Secretary Clinton indicated, and I agree with that, that there should be a political process.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But we shouldn't be the ones declaring that Assad must go.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Where did it ever say in the Constitution, where is it written that it's the job of the United States of America or its secretary of State to determine when dictators have to go?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We have a role to play in this world.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But it is not the world -- the role of traveling the world looking for new monsters to destroy.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: SANDERS
text: David...

speaker: CLINTON
text: Since he has been making all kinds of comments.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think it's fair to say, Assad has killed, by last count, about 250,000 Syrians.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The reason we are in the mess we're in, that ISIS has the territory it has, is because of Assad.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I advocated arming the moderate opposition back in the day when I was still secretary of State, because I worried we would end up exactly where we are now.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so, when we look at these complex problems, I wish it could be either/or.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I wish we could say yes, let's go destroy ISIS and let's let Assad continue to destroy Syria, which creates more terrorists, more extremists by the minute.

speaker: CLINTON
text: No.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We now finally are where we need to be.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have a strategy and a commitment to go after ISIS, which is a danger to us as well as the region...

speaker: SANDERS
text: Secretary...

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we finally have a U.N. Security Council Resolution bringing the world together to go after a political transition in Syria.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Could I just say -- just say this...

speaker: CLINTON
text: If the United States does not lead, there is not another leader.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There is a vacuum.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Can I just say this...

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we have to lead, if we're going to be successful.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders, please.

speaker: MUIR
text: Go ahead.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders, a last word on this.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Of course the United States must lead.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But the United States is not the policeman of the world.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The United States must not be involved in perpetual warfare in the Middle East.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The United States, at the same time, cannot successfully fight Assad and ISIS.

speaker: SANDERS
text: ISIS, now, is the major priority.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's get rid of Assad later.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let's have a Democratic Syria.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But the first task is to bring countries together to destroy ISIS.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders, thank you.

speaker: SANDERS
text: When we come back here tonight, the other major issues of this election: jobs, the economy, health care.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Which candidates will make the best case for the middle class, as our coverage of the Democratic debate, here in New Hampshire, continues right after this on ABC.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: ABC News coverage of the New Hampshire Democratic debate will continue in a moment.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: MUIR
text: Welcome back tonight.

speaker: MUIR
text: As you can see, we have a packed audience here in New Hampshire and we're going to continue.

speaker: MUIR
text: We've already had a spirited conversation here at the top of the broadcast about ISIS, about the concerns of terror here on the homefront and as we await Secretary Clinton backstage, we're going to begin on the economy.

speaker: MUIR
text: We want to turn to the American jobs, wages and raises in this country.

speaker: MUIR
text: And we believe Secretary Clinton will be coming around the corner any minute.

speaker: MUIR
text: But in the mean time we want to start with this eye-opening number.

speaker: MUIR
text: And Senator Sanders, this question goes to you first, anyway.

speaker: MUIR
text: In 1995, the median American household income was $52,600 in today's money.

speaker: MUIR
text: This year, it's $53,600.

speaker: MUIR
text: That's 20 more years on the job with just a 2 percent raise.

speaker: MUIR
text: In a similar time-frame, raises for CEOs went up more than 200 percent.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Sorry.

speaker: MUIR
text: We're going to continue here, and Secretary, you'll get a chance on this too.

speaker: MUIR
text: But as I pointed out the CEO pay, 200 percent of their time -- for that family of just 2 percent.

speaker: MUIR
text: You've all said, "you would raise the minimum wage."

speaker: MUIR
text: But Senator Sanders what else - speak to that household tonight.

speaker: MUIR
text: 20 years, just a 2 percent raise, how as president would you get them a raise right away?

speaker: SANDERS
text: First of all, we recognize that we have a rigged economy, as you've indicated.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Middle class in this country for the last 40 years has been disappearing; are we better of today then we were when Bush left office?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Absolutely.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But as you've indicated for millions of American workers, people in New Hampshire -- all over America, they're working longer hours for lower wages deeply worried about their kids.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So what do we do?

speaker: SANDERS
text: First statement is, we tell the billionaire class, "they cannot have it all."

speaker: SANDERS
text: For a start, they're going to start to pay their fair share of taxes.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Second of all what we do, is you raise the minimum wage to living wage, 15 bucks an hour over the next several years.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Next thing we do, pay equity for women workers.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Women should not be making 79 cents on the dollar compared to that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Next thing that we do, real unemployment -- official unemployment, 5 percent, real employment 10 percent, youth unemployment, off the charts.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We rebuild our crumbling infrastructure, our roads our bridges, our rail systems, we create 13 million jobs with a trillion-dollar investment.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Furthermore, in a competitive global economy, it is imperative that we have the best educated workforce in the world.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is why I'm going to have a tax on Wall Street speculation to make certain that public colleges and universities in America are tuition free.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor O'Malley, what would propose that would be different, how would you get the middle class a raise and without waiting another 20 years for another 2 percent.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Look these are the things that we did in own state through the recession.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We actually passed a living wage.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We raised the minimum wage.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We actually raised it to the highest goals of any state in the nation also in minority and women participant goals because we understood that the way you reinvigorate and make fair market American capitalism work, is to make the choices and the investments that include more people more full in the economic success of your state.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: All through the recession, we defended the highest median income in America and the second highest median income for African American families.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: How?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: By actually doing more for education.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We increased education funding by 37 percent.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We were the only state in American that went four years in a row without a penny increase in college tuition.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We invested more in our infrastructure and we squared our shoulders to the great business opportunity of this era and that is moving our economy to a 100 percent clean electric energy future.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We created 2,000 new jobs in the solar industry and we fought every single day to adopt more inclusive economic practices.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: So David, the conclusion of all of those things is this; they weren't hopes, they weren't dreams, they weren't amorphous goals out there.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We actually took action to do these things and as president, I have put forward 15 strategic goals that will make wages go up again for all American families.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Universal national service is an option for every kid in America to cut youth employment.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And I'm the only candidate on this stage to put forward a new agenda for America's cities so we can employ more people in the heart of great American cities and get them back to work.

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: As you were walking in, I was talking about the median American household getting a two percent raise over the last 20 years, that CEO pay in that same time frame has gone up 200 percent.

speaker: MUIR
text: So for those families watching tonight, how do you get them a raise if you're president?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I've been talking to a lot of these families, and this is such an outrage, both because it's bad for our economy, we're a 70 percent consumption economy, people need to feel optimistic and confident, they need to believe their hard work is going to be rewarded, and it's bad for our democracy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: It's absolutely the case that if people feel that the game is rigged, that has consequences.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think it's great standing up here with the senator and the governor talking about these issues, because you're not going to hear anything like this from any of the Republicans who are running for president.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: They don't want to raise the minimum wage, they don't want to do anything to increase incomes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: At the center of my economic policy is raising incomes, because people haven't been able to get ahead, and the cost of everything, from college tuition to prescription drugs, has gone up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Of course we have to raise the minimum wage.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Of course we have to do more to incentivize profit sharing, like we see with Market Basket right here in New Hampshire and New England, where all of the employees get a chance to share in the profits.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we've got to do more on equal pay for equal work.

speaker: CLINTON
