text: That means pass the Paycheck Fairness Act so we have transparency about how much people are making.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's the way to get women's wages up, and that's good for them and good for their families and good for our communities.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: And there is a lot we can do in college affordability.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have debt-free tuition plans, free community college plans, getting student debt down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I also am very committed to getting the price of drugs down.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And there's a lot.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You can go to my website...

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary...

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... hillaryclinton.com, and read about it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I guess the final thing that -- that I would say is this is the kind of debate we need to take to the Republicans in the fall.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary, thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: This is the election...

speaker: MUIR
text: We're going to -- we're going to...

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... issues they have to respond to.

speaker: MUIR
text: And we're going to talk about college education in a moment.

speaker: MUIR
text: But Secretary Clinton, I did want to ask you, the last time you ran for president, Fortune Magazine put you on its cover with the headline Business Loves Hillary, pointing out your support for many CEOs in corporate America.

speaker: MUIR
text: I'm curious, eight years later, should corporate America love Hillary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Everybody should.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Look, I have said I want to be the president for the struggling, the striving and the successful.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to make sure the wealthy pay their fair share, which they have not been doing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want the Buffett Rule to be in effect, where millionaires have to pay 30 percent tax rates instead of 10 percent to nothing in some cases.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to make sure we rein in the excessive use of political power to feather the nest and support the super wealthy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I also want to create jobs and I want to be a partner with the private sector.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm particularly keen on creating jobs in small business.

speaker: CLINTON
text: My dad was a small businessman, a really small business.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I want to do more to help incentivize and create more small businesses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So if -- if people who are in the private sector know what I stand for, it's what I fought for as a senator, it's what I will do as president, and they want to be part of once again building our economy so it works for everybody, more power to them, because they are the kind of business leaders who understand that if we don't get the American economy moving and growing, we're not going to recognize our country and we're not going to give our kids the same opportunities that we had.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: I want to stay on this and ask you how big a role does corporate America play in a healthy economy and will corporate America love a President Sanders?

speaker: SANDERS
text: No, I think they won't.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: So Hillary and I have a difference.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The CEOs of large multinationals may like Hillary.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They ain't going to like me and Wall Street is going to like me even less.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And the reason for that is we've got to deal with the elephant in the room, which is the greed, recklessness and illegal behavior on Wall Street.

speaker: SANDERS
text: When you have six financial institutions in this country that issue two-thirds of the credit cards and one-third of the mortgages, when three out of four of them are larger today than when we bailed them out because they are too big to fail, we've got to re- establish Glass-Steagall, we have got to break the large financial institutions up.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I don't think...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: ... having said that, I don't think I'm going to get a whole lot of campaign contributions from Wall Street.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I don't have a super PAC.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I don't want campaign contributions from corporate America.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And let me be clear: While there are some great corporations creating jobs and trying to do the right thing, in my view -- and I say this very seriously -- the greed of the billionaire class, the greed of Wall Street is destroying this economy and is destroying the lives of millions of Americans.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We need an economy that works for the middle class, not just a handful of billionaires, and I will fight and lead to make that happen.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: I want to...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor, let me just ask you, though, because it is an important question, how important a role do you think corporate America plays in a healthy economy here in the U.S.?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Look, I look at our economy as an ecosystem.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And the fact of the matter is that the more fully people participate, the more our workers earn, the more they will spend, the more our economy will grow.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And most heads of businesses -- large, medium and small -- understand that.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But there is a better way forward than either of those offered by my two opponents here on this stage.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We're not going to fix what ails our economy, we're not going to make wages go up for everyone by either trying to replace American capitalism with socialism -- which, by the way, the rest of the world is moving away from -- nor will we fix it by submitting to sort of Wall Street-directed crony capitalism.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And for my part, I have demonstrated the ability to have the backbone to take on Wall Street in ways that Secretary Clinton never, ever has.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: In fact, in the last debate, very shamefully, she tried to hide her cozy relationship with Wall Street big banks by invoking the attacks of 9/11.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I believe that the way forward for our country is to actually reinvigorate our antitrust department with the directive to promote fair competition.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: There's mergers that are happening in every aspect of our country that is bad for competition and it's bad for -- for upward mobility of wages.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And the worst type of concentration, Secretary Clinton, is the concentration of the big banks, the big six banks that you went to and spoke to and told them, oh, you weren't responsible for the crash, not by a long shot.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And that's why today you still cannot support, as I do, breaking up the big banks and making sure that we pass a modern-day Glass- Steagall, like we had in late 1999, before it was repealed and led to the crash, where so many millions of families lost their jobs and their homes.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And I was on the front lines of that, looking into the eyes of my neighbors...

speaker: CLINTON
text: OK...

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor O'Malley, thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: MUIR
text: I do want to ask you, Secretary Clinton.

speaker: MUIR
text: Let me just ask you...

speaker: CLINTON
text: Let me respond...

speaker: MUIR
text: We did -- we did -- Secretary Clinton, let me just ask you...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Under the rules, I have been -- I have been invoked, David, so let me respond very quickly.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number one...

speaker: MUIR
text: And in particular...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number one, there are currently two hedge fund billionaires running ads against me here in New Hampshire.

speaker: CLINTON
text: They started in Iowa.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, you'd have to ask yourself, why are they running ads against me?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And the answer is: Because they know I will go right after them, that I will not let their agenda be America's agenda.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Secondly, I think it's important to point out that about 3 percent of my donations come from people in the finance and investment world.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You can go to opensecrets.org and check that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have more donations from students and teachers than I do from people associated with Wall Street.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, number three -- and let me say this -- when Governor O'Malley was heading the Democratic Governors Association, he had no trouble at all going to Wall Street to raise money to run campaigns for Democratic governors.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And he also had no trouble appointing an investment banker to be in charge of his consumer protection bureau when he was governor.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, you know, again, the difference between us and the Republicans is night and day.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And there is only one person on this stage who voted to take away authority from the SEC and the Commodities Future Trading Commission that they could no longer regulate what are called swaps and derivatives, which actually contributed to the collapse of Lehman Brothers, and that was Senator Sanders.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So if we're going to be talking like this, we can -- and maybe we can score some political points -- but the fact is: Every one of us stands for the kind of economy that will work better for every American.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And if that means taking on Wall Street, I have a plan that is tough and comprehensive and praised by a lot of folks who say it goes further than what both Senator Sanders and Governor O'Malley are proposing.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me just -- let me just...

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton, thank you.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me just jump in.

speaker: SANDERS
text: My name was invoked.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator?

speaker: SANDERS
text: So with that invocation, let me say a few words.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Secretary Clinton, I don't have a super PAC.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I don't get any money from Wall Street.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You have gotten a whole lot of money over the years from Wall Street.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But most importantly, when you look at what happened in the 1990s, go to berniesanders.com.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'll advertise my Web site as well.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And what you'll find is that I led -- helped lead the effort as a member of the House financial committee against Alan Greenspan, against a guy named Bill Clinton, maybe you know him, maybe you don't.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Against the Republican leadership, who all thought it would be a great idea to merge investor banks and commercial banks and large insurance companies.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What a brilliant idea that would be.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Go to YouTube.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Find out what I said to Greenspan.

speaker: SANDERS
text: At the end of the day, if Teddy Roosevelt were alive today, and the governor makes a good point about trade, anti-trade, anti-monopoly activities.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Wall Street today has too much political power.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It has too much economic power.

speaker: SANDERS
text: To get deregulated -- listen to this, they spent $5 billion in lobbying and campaign contributions over a 10-year period.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders...

speaker: SANDERS
text: Wall Street is a threat to the economy.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They've got to be broken up.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Thank you, Senator.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And we're going to move on to health care.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Secretary Clinton, the Department of Health and Human Services says more than 17 million Americans who are not insured now have health coverage because of Obamacare.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But for Americans who already had health insurance the cost has gone up 27 percent in the last five years while deductibles are up 67 percent, health care costs are rising faster than many Americans can manage.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What's broken in Obamacare that needs to be fixed right now?

speaker: SANDERS
text: And what would you do to fix it?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I would certainly build on the successes of the Affordable Care Act and work to fix some of the glitches that you just referenced.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number one, we do have more people who have access to health care.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have ended the terrible situation that people with pre- existing conditions were faced with where they couldn't find at any affordable price health care.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Women are not charged more than men any longer for our health insurance.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we keep young people on our policies until they turn 26.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Those are all really positive developments.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But out-of-pocket costs have gone up too much and prescription drug costs have gone through the roof.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so what I have proposed, number one, is a $5,000 tax credit to help people who have very large out-of-pocket costs be able to afford those.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number two, I want Medicare to be able to negotiate for lower drug prices just like they negotiate with other countries' health systems.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: We end up paying the highest prices in the world.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I want us to be absolutely clear about making sure the insurance companies in the private employer policy arena as well as in the Affordable Care exchanges are properly regulated so that we are not being gamed.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think that's an important point to make because I'm going through and analyzing the points you were making, Martha.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We don't have enough competition and we don't have enough oversight of what the insurance companies are charging everybody right now.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But you did say those were glitches.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Just glitches?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, they're glitches because...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Twenty-seven percent in the last five years, deductibles up 67 percent?

speaker: CLINTON
text: It is.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because part of this is the startup challenges that this system is facing.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have fought, as Democrats, for decades to get a health care plan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I know.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've got the scars to show from the effort back in the early '90s.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We want to build on it and fix it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I'm confident we can do that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And it will have effects in the private market.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And one of the reasons in some states why the percentage cost has gone up so much is because governors there would not extend Medicaid.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And so people are still going to get health care, thankfully, in emergency rooms, in hospitals.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Those costs are then added to the overall cost, which does increase the insurance premiums for people in the private system.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Senator Sanders, I want you to respond to what she was saying, but you're instead calling for single-payer health care.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes, exactly, exactly.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You note people won't have to pay deductibles or premiums but they will have to pay new taxes.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Can you tell us specifically how much people will be expected to pay?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes, well, roughly.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me say this.

speaker: SANDERS
text: As a member of the Health Education Committee that helped write the Affordable Care Act, much of what Secretary Clinton said about what we have done, among other things, ending the obscenity of this pre-existing situation is a step forward.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Seventeen more million more people have health care.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is a step forward.

speaker: SANDERS
text: A step forward.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But this is what we also have to say.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Not only are deductibles rising, 29 million Americans still have no health insurance and millions of people can't afford to go to the doctor.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Major crisis and primary health care.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Here is the bottom line.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Why is it that the United States of America today is the only major country on earth that does not guarantee health care to all people as a right?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Why is it...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: Why is it that we are -- why is it that we spend almost three times per capita as to what they spend in the U.K., 50 percent more than what they pay in France, countries that guarantee health care to all of their people and in many cases, have better health care outcomes.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Bottom line.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This ties into campaign finance reform.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The insurance companies, the drug companies are bribing the United States Congress.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We need to pass a Medicare for all single payer system.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It will lower the cost of health care for a middle-class family by thousands of dollars a year.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Senator Sanders, you didn't really tell us specifically how much people will be expected to pay...

speaker: SANDERS
text: But they will not be paying, Martha, any private insurance.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So it's unfair to say in total...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But you can't tell us this specifically, even if you were...

speaker: SANDERS
text: I can tell you that adding up the fact you're not paying any private insurance, businesses are not paying any private insurance.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The average middle-class family will be saving thousands of dollars a year.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: OK.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Let's go to talk about the high cost of college education and for that we turn to the executive director of the New Hampshire Institute of Politics, right here at Saint Anselm college, Neil Levesque.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Neil?

speaker: LEVESQUE
text: Here to New Hampshire again.

speaker: LEVESQUE
text: As you know, this auditorium is filled with many Saint Anselm college students.

speaker: LEVESQUE
text: They know the outstanding student debt right now in America is $1.3 trillion.

speaker: LEVESQUE
text: That private education costs have gone up in the last decade 26 percent, and 40 percent for public education.

speaker: LEVESQUE
text: So knowing that, we know you want to make public education more affordable but how do you really lower the cost?

speaker: LEVESQUE
text: Senator Sanders, you mentioned a few minutes ago that you want free tuition for public colleges.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And universities.

speaker: LEVESQUE
text: How does that really lower the cost other than just shifting the cost to taxpayers?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, Neil, I think we've got to work on a two-pronged approach.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And your point is absolutely well taken.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The cost of college education is escalating a lot faster than the cost of inflation.

speaker: SANDERS
text: There are a lot of factors involved in that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that is that we have some colleges and universities that are spending a huge amount of money on fancy dormitories and on giant football stadiums.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Maybe we should focus on quality education with well-paid faculty members.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I understand in many universities a heck of a lot of vice presidents who earn a big salary.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But, bottom line is this is the year 2015.

speaker: SANDERS
text: If we are going to be competitive in the global economy we need the best educated workforce.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is insane to my mind, hundreds of thousands of young people today, bright qualified people, cannot go to college because they cannot afford -- their families cannot afford to send them.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Millions coming out of school as you indicated, deeply in debt.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What do we do?

speaker: SANDERS
text: My proposal is to put a speculation tax on wall street, raise very substantial sums of money, not only make public colleges and universities tuition-free, but also substantially lower interest rates on student debt.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You have families out there paying 6 percent, 8 percent, 10 percent on student debt, refinance their homes at 3 percent.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What sense is that?

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I think we need radical changes in the funding of higher education.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We should look at college today the way high school was looked at 60 years ago.

speaker: SANDERS
text: All young people who have the ability should be able to get a college education.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: LEVESQUE
text: Governor O'Malley, how do you propose -- Governor O'Malley, how do you propose lowering some of these costs associated with higher education?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Yes, this one falls under the category of, I have actually done this.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: As a governor we actually made the greater investments so that we could go four years in a row without a penny's increase to college tuition.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: My plan actually goes further than Senator Sanders because a big chunk of the cost is actually room and board and books and fees.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: So as a nation we need to increase what we invest in Pell grants.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Yes, we need to make it easier for parents to refinance.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But states need to do more as well.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And I propose a block grant program that will keep the states in the game as well.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I believe that all of our kids should go into an income-based repayment plan.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I'm joined tonight by two daughters, Tara and Grace.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: My oldest daughter's a teacher.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Man (ph), their mother's here as well.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We were proud of them on graduation day, weren't we, Katie?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And we're going to be proud every month for the rest of our lives.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I mean, we had to borrow so much money to send them to college and were not the only ones.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: There're families all across America who aren't able to contribute to our economy because of this crushing student loan.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I also propose that we can pay for this with a tax on high volume trades and we need to because my dad came to college after World War II on a G.I.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Bill.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But today, we're the only nation on the planet that's saddling our kids with a lifetime of bills.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: That's a drag on the economy.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: It's one of the key investments we need to make.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I was flattered that Secretary Clinton two months later borrowed so many of my proposals to incorporate into hers.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And in our party, unlike the Republican party, we actually believe that the more our people learn, the more they will earn and higher education should be a right for every kid.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Right.

speaker: MCELVEEN
text: Secretary Clinton, how does your plan differentiate from your opponents?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I have what I call the new college compact.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because I think everybody has to have some skin in this game, you know.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Number one, States have been dis-investing in higher education.

speaker: CLINTON
text: In fact, I think New Hampshire, in state tuition for public colleges and universities, is among the highest if not the highest in the country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So states over a period of decades have put their money elsewhere; into prisons, into highways, into things other than higher education.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So under my compact, the federal government will match money that the states begin to put back in to the higher education system.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Secondly, I don't believe in free tuition for everybody.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I believe we should focus on middle-class families, working families, and poor kids who have the ambition and the talent to go to college and get ahead.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I have proposed debt free tuition, which I think is affordable and I would move a lot of the Pell Grant and other aid into the arena where it could be used for living expense.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I put all of this together, again, on my website and I've gotten such a good response.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I want to quickly say, one of the areas that Senator Sanders touched on in talking about education and certainly talking about health care is his commitment to really changing the systems.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Free college, a single payer system for health, and it's been estimated were looking at 18 to $20 trillion, about a 40 percent in the federal budget.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I have looked at his proposed plans for health care for example, and it really does transfer every bit of our health care system including private health care, to the states to have the states run.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think we've got to be really thoughtful about how we're going to afford what we proposed, which is why everything that I have proposed I will tell you exactly how I'm going to pay for it; including college.

speaker: MCELVEEN
text: Thank you Secretary Clinton, thank you.

speaker: SANDERS
text: May I respond to the critique on the ...

speaker: MCELVEEN
text: Back to you David.

speaker: MUIR
text: We're going to get right into this Senator but I want to ask about taxes next.

speaker: MUIR
text: This is included.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I would just...

speaker: MUIR
text: She was asking about that...

speaker: SANDERS
text: But Secretary Clinton is wrong.

speaker: SANDERS
text: As you know, because I know you know a lot about health care.

speaker: SANDERS
text: You know that the United States per capita pays far and away more than other country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And it is unfair simply to say how much more the program will cost without making sure that people know that, we are doing away with cost of private insurance and that the middle class will be paying substantially less for health care on the single payer than on the Secretary's Clinton proposal.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, the only thing - the only thing I can go on Senator Sanders...

speaker: MUIR
text: Are we back on health care - Secretary Clinton hold one moment.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Your proposal is to go and send the health care system to the state.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton, please.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And my analysis is, that you are going to get more taxes out of middle class families.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I'm the only person...

speaker: MUIR
text: So let's ask about it.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton, let's turn to the taxes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... saying, no middle class tax raises.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's off the table...

speaker: MUIR
text: This is where we are going next, we are going next to taxes here...

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now, this is getting to be fun.

speaker: MUIR
text: This is fun.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: This is democracy at work.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton, let me ask you about your tax plan because from the crushing cost of college education, the next question most families have; is will my taxes go up under the next president?

speaker: MUIR
text: You have said it's your goal not to raise taxes on families making under $200,000 a year a goal.

speaker: MUIR
text: But can you say that's a promise as you stand here tonight?

speaker: CLINTON
text: That is a pledge that I'm making.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I made it when I ran in 2008.

speaker: MUIR
text: A promise?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Yes, and it was the same one that President Obama made.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Because I don't think we should be imposing new big programs that are going to raise middle class families' taxes.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We just heard that most families haven't had a wage increase since 2001.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Since, you know, the end of the last Clinton administration when incomes did go up for everybody.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we've got to get back to where people can save money again, where they can invest in their families, and I don't think a middle-class tax should be part of anybody's plan right now.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me respond to...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton...

speaker: SANDERS
text: Let me respond to...

speaker: MUIR
text: Please.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Number one, most important economic reality of today is that over the last 30 years, there has been a transfer of trillions of dollars from the middle class to the top one-tenth of one percent who are seeing a doubling of the percentage of wealth that they own.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now, when Secretary Clinton says, "I'm not going raise taxes on the middle class," let me tell you what she is saying.

speaker: SANDERS
text: She is disagreeing with FDR on Social Security, LBJ on Medicare and with the vast majority of progressive Democrats in the House and the Senate, who today are fighting to end the disgrace of the United States being the only major country on Earth that doesn't provide paid family and medical leave.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What the legislation is is $1.61 a week.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now, you can say that's a tax on the middle class.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It will provide three months paid family and medical leave for the working families of this country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think, Secretary Clinton, $1.61 a week is a pretty good invest.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: Let me bring in Governor O'Malley...

speaker: CLINTON
text: Senator, I have been -- I have been fighting for paid...

speaker: MUIR
text: You've heard...

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... family leave for a very long time...

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton.

speaker: SANDERS
text: David, thank you.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I have a way to pay for it that actually makes the wealthiest pay for it...

speaker: SANDERS
text: Then (inaudible)...

speaker: CLINTON
text: ... not everybody else.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Every (inaudible) Democrat and senator in support of this proposal introduced by your good friend and my good friend, Kirsten Gillibrand, Rosa DeLauro, got ears (ph) to legislation out there that will finally provide family and medical leave.

speaker: MUIR
text: Thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: I want to bring in Governor O'Malley on this.

speaker: MUIR
text: We heard the promise from Secretary Clinton because people want to know about their taxes, will they go up.

speaker: MUIR
text: She has now promised here tonight not to raise them on families making $250,000 or less.

speaker: MUIR
text: Can you make that same promise if you're elected?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: No, I've never made a promise like that.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But unlike either of these two fine people, I've actually balanced a budget every single year.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I was one -- I was the only -- one of only seven states that had a AAA bond rating.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: By the time I left, the average tax burden on Maryland families was the same as when I started.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But I did pass a more progressive income tax and asked the highest-earning people to pay another 14 percent.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: David, look, this is the big -- I agree, by the way, that we should have paid family leave.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And I agree with Senator Sanders on that.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And just like Social Security and unlike the Republicans, I think we should actually expand Social Security and increase average monthly benefits.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But look, there's one big entitlement we can no longer afford as a country, and that is the entitlement that the super wealthy among us, those earning more than a million dollars, feel that they're entitled to pay lower income tax rates and a far lower preferred income tax rate when it comes to capital gains.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: If we were to raise the marginal rate to 45 percent for people earning more than a million dollars and if we tax capital gains essentially the same we do earnings from hard work and sweat and toil, you could generate $800 billion over the next ten years and that would do so much good for affordable college, debt-free college, cutting youth unemployment in half, investing in our cities again.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: So the things I have done in office are the things that actually invest in growing our economy and making wages go up.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: That's the issue that we need to tackle as Americans, and we can do it and we know how.

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor O'Malley, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: A spirited debate on taxes.

speaker: MUIR
text: And there will be more with the Democratic debate in New Hampshire, when we come back right here on ABC.

speaker: MUIR
text: More in a moment.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: MUIR
text: Welcome back tonight to New Hampshire.

speaker: MUIR
text: The Democratic debate continues here on ABC.

speaker: MUIR
text: And Secretary Clinton, we want to turn to race, now, in America.

speaker: MUIR
text: There is a real concern in this country from Black Lives Matter and from other community groups that we're just now seeing, with smartphones and cell phones, what many have been dealing with for years when they come in contact with police.

speaker: MUIR
text: But you also have many in law enforcement who now say there has been a so-called Ferguson effect, police holding back because they're afraid of backlash.

speaker: MUIR
text: In fact, the FBI director is calling it a chill wind blowing through American law enforcement.

speaker: MUIR
text: So, if elected president, how would you bridge the divide between the two?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, David, I think this is one of the most important challenges facing not just our next president but our country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We have systemic racism and injustice and inequities in our country and in particular, in our justice system that must be addressed and must be ended.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I feel very strongly that we have to reform our criminal justice system and we have to find ways to try to bring law enforcement together again with the communities that they are sworn to protect.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Trust has been totally lost in a lot of places.

speaker: CLINTON
text: At the same time, we know that in many parts of our country police officers are bridging those divides and they're acting heroically.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The young officer who was killed responding to the Planned Parenthood murders.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The officer who told the victims of the San Bernardino killings that he would take a bullet before them.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So I think that we need to build on the work of the policing commissioner that President Obama impaneled.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need to get a bipartisan commitment to work together on this.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we need to hear the voices of those men and women and boys and girls who feel like strangers in their own country and do whatever is necessary to not only deal with the immediate problems within the criminal justice system, but more opportunities, more jobs, better education so that we can begin to rebuild that very valuable asset known as trust.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary, thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor O'Malley, how would you bridge the divide?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: There is no issue in American public policy that I have worked on more day in and day out than this painful issue of policing, of law enforcement, criminal justice and race in America.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: When I ran in 1999, David, for mayor of Baltimore, our city by that year had become the most addicted, violent, and abandoned in America.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But we came together.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I brought people together over some very deep racial divides.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And we were able to put our city on the path for the biggest reduction in crime of any major city in America over the next ten years.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: As governor, we continued to work together.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We reduced violent crime to 30-year lows.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But get this.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We also reduced incarceration rates to 20-year lows.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: So it is possible actually, to find the things that actually work, that we did, increasing drug treatment, using big data to better protect the lives of young people, cut juvenile crime in half, and it's also possible to improve how we police our police.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But there wasn't a single day as mayor of Baltimore that I wasn't asked whether I was delivering on the promise I made to police the police.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We reported excessive force, discourtesy, use of lethal force.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: In fact, drove down to three of the four lowest years on record police use of lethal force.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: As a nation, we have to embrace this moment and make our departments more open, more transparent, and more accountable.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Just as we require every major department, every county to report its major crimes, we should require police departments to report their discourtesy, brutality, excessive force.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: There's so much work that can be done, so much we've learned to do better.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We need to do it now as a nation.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: This is our time and our opportunity to do that.

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor, thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: And Senator Sanders, when you hear the FBI director calling it a chill wind blowing through American law enforcement, does that concern you as well when you --

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, this whole issue concerns me.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And I agree with much of what the secretary and the governor have said.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But let's be clear.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Today in America we have more people in jail than any other country on earth, 2.2 million people.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Predominantly African-American and Hispanic.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We are spending $80 billion a year locking up our fellow Americans.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I think, and this is not easy, but I think we need to make wage a major effort, to come together as a country and end institutional racism.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We need major, major reforms of a very broken criminal justice system.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Now, what does that mean?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, for a start it means that police officers should not be shooting unarmed people, predominantly African-Americans.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: It means that we have to rethink the so-called war on drugs which has destroyed the lives of millions of people, which is why I have taken marijuana out of the Controlled Substance Act.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So that it will not be a federal crime.

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is why we need to make...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: That is why we need to make police -- and I speak as a former mayor.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I was a mayor for eight years, worked very closely with a great police department.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And what we did is try to move that department toward community policing, so that the police officers become part of the community and not, as we see, in some cities an oppressive force.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We need to make police departments look like the communities they serve in terms of diversity.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We need to end minimal sentencing.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We need, basically, to pledge that we're going to invest in this country, in jobs and education, not more jails and incarceration.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: We want to turn now to an issue.

speaker: MUIR
text: This next issue has destroyed so many families across the country, and in particular right here in New Hampshire, heroin.

speaker: MUIR
text: And there's a stunning new figure out.

speaker: MUIR
text: A recent poll -- 48 percent here, in this state alone, say they know someone who has abused heroin.

speaker: MUIR
text: We're going to turn tonight to Dan Tuohy of the New Hampshire Union Leader who has this question.

speaker: QUESTION
text: New Hampshire has been hard hit by the heroin epidemic, and we're on track to have twice as many overdose deaths this year as in 2013.

speaker: QUESTION
text: What specifically would you do to address this crisis?

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders, I'm going to take this to you first because you've seen what's happened with heroin right on the border in your own state.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Yes.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Look, this is a tragedy for New Hampshire.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is a tragedy for my state of Vermont.

speaker: SANDERS
text: It is a tragedy all over this country.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The number of heroin deaths are growing very, very significantly.

speaker: SANDERS
text: What do we do?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, for a start, this may seem like a radical idea, but I think we have got to tell the medical profession and doctors who are prescribing opiates and the pharmaceutical industry that they have got to start getting their act together, we cannot have this huge number of opiates out there throughout this country, where young people are taking them, getting hooked, and then going to heroin.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Second of all, and the reason I believe in a health care for all program, we need to understand that addiction is a disease, not a criminal activity.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that means -- and that means radically changing the way we deal with mental health and addiction issues.

speaker: SANDERS
text: When somebody is addicted and seeking help, they should not have to wait three, four months in order to get that help.

speaker: SANDERS
text: They should be able to walk in the door tomorrow and get a variety of treatments that work for them.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So those are some of the areas that I think we've got to move on.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary Clinton?

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, on my very first visit to New Hampshire in this campaign, I was in Keene, and I was asked what are you going to do about the heroin epidemic?

speaker: CLINTON
text: And all over New Hampshire, I met grandmothers who are raising children because they lost the father or the mother to an overdose.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I met young people who are desperately trying to get clean and have nowhere to go, because there are not enough facilities.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So this is a major epidemic, and it has hit New Hampshire and Vermont particularly hard.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I've had had two town halls, one in Keene, one in Laconia, dedicated exclusively to talking about what we can do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I've heard some great ideas about how law enforcement is changing its behavior, how the recovery community is reaching out.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I was proud to get the endorsement of Mayor Walsh of Boston, who has made his struggle with alcoholism a real clarion call for action in this arena.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So, I've laid out a five-point plan about what we can do together.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I would like the federal government to offer $10 billion over ten years to work with states, and I really applaud Governor Hassan for taking up this challenge and working with the legislature here to come up with a plan.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We need to do more on the prescribing end of it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: There are too many opioids being prescribed, and that leads directly now to heroin addiction.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And we need to change the way we do law enforcement, and of course, we need more programs and facilities, so when somebody is ready to get help, there's a place for them to go.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And every law enforcement should carry the antidote to overdose, Naloxone, so that they can save lives that are on the brink of expiring.

speaker: MUIR
text: Secretary, thank you.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And you know, I actually know a great deal about this issue.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And I have a dear friend, played music with him for years, remember when his -- when he came home with his baby girl, and now she's no longer with us, because of addiction and overdose.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: The last time in New Hampshire, I had to take a break shortly after landing and call home and comfort a friend whose mother had died of an overdose.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Drugs have taken far too many of our citizens.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: It's a huge public health challenge.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: In our own city, I mentioned before, we had become the most addicted city in America.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But together, every single year, I expanded drug treatment funding within our city and then I expanded it in our state, and we were saving lives every single year doing the things that work, intervening earlier, understanding the continuum of care that's required until we got hit like every other state in the state -- in the United States, especially in New Hampshire and in the northeast with this opioid addiction, the over-prescribing.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I agree, we need better -- we need to rein in the over- prescribing, but I have put forward on my -- in my plan a $12 billion federal investment.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We have to invest in the local partnerships, and the best place to intervene, the best indicator of when a person is actually on the verge of killing themselves because of an addiction, is at the hospital.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: That very first time they show up with a near miss, we should be intervening there.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: That's what I said to my own public health people.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: What would we do if this were ebola?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: How would we act?

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: So many more Americans have been killed by the combination of heroin and these highly addictive pain pills, and yet, we refuse to act.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: There are thing that can be done.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Go on to my website.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: My plan is there.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: It's one of 15 strategic goals I've set out to make our country a better place by cutting these sort of deaths in half in the next five years.

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor O'Malley, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: Martha?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, I want to circle back to something that your opponents here have brought up.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Libya is falling apart.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The country is a haven for ISIS and jihadists with an estimated 2,000 ISIS fighters there today.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You advocated for that 2011 intervention and called it smart power at its best.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And yet, even President Obama said the U.S. should have done more to fill the leadership vacuum left behind.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: How much responsibility do you bear for the chaos that followed elections?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, first, let's remember why we became part of a coalition to stop Gadhafi from committing massacres against his people.

speaker: CLINTON
text: The United States was asked to support the Europeans and the Arab partners that we had and we did a lot of due diligence about whether we should or not, and eventually, yes, I recommended and the president decided that we would support the action to protect civilians on the ground and that led to the overthrow of Gadhafi.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think that what Libya then did by having a full free election, which elected moderates, was an indication of their crying need and desire to get on the right path.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, the whole region has been rendered unstable, in part because of the aftermath of the Arab Spring, in part because of the very effective outreach and propagandizing that ISIS and other terrorist groups do.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But what we're seeing happening in Libya right now is that there has been a fragile agreement to put aside the differences that exist among Libyans themselves to try to dislodge ISIS from Sirte, the home town of Gadhafi, and to begin to try to create a national government.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, this is not easy work.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We did a lot to help.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We did as much as we could because the Libyans themselves had very strong feelings about what they wished to accept.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But we're always looking for ways about what more we can do to try to give people a chance to be successful.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, I want to go back.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: That -- government lacked institutions and experience.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: It had been a family business for 40 years.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: On the security side, we offered only a modest training effort and a very limited arms buy-back program.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Let me ask you the question again.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: How much responsibility do you bear for the chaos that followed those elections?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Martha, we offered a lot more than they were willing to take.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We offered a lot more.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We also got rid of their chemical weapons, which was a big help, and we also went after a lot of the shoulder-fired missiles to round them up.

speaker: CLINTON
text: You know, we can't -- if we're not going to send American troops, which there was never any idea of doing that, then to try to send trainers, to try to send experts, is something we offered, Europeans offered, the U.N. offered, and there wasn't a lot of responsiveness at first.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think a lot of the Libyans who had been forced out of their country by Gadhafi who came back to try to be part of a new government, believed they knew what to do and it turned out that they were no match for some of the militaristic forces inside that country.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I'm not giving up on Libya and I don't think anybody should.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We've been at this a couple of years.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But were mistakes made?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, there's always a retrospective to say what mistakes were made.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I know that we offered a lot of help and I know it was difficult for the Libyans to accept help.

speaker: CLINTON
text: What we could have done if they had said yes would have been a lot more than what we were able to have done.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But what...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Senator Sanders.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Look, the secretary is right.

speaker: SANDERS
text: This is a terribly complicated issue.

speaker: SANDERS
text: There are no simple solutions.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But where we have a disagreement is that I think if you look at the history of regime changes, you go back to Mossaddegh (ph) in Iran, you go back to Salvador Allende who we overthrew in Chile, you go back to overthrowing Saddam Hussein in Iraq, you go back to where we are today in Syria with a dictator named Assad.

speaker: SANDERS
text: The truth is it is relatively easy for a powerful nation like America to overthrow a dictator but it is very hard to predict the unintended consequences and the turmoil and the instability that follows after you overthrow that dictator.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I think secretary Clinton and I have a fundamental disagreement.

speaker: SANDERS
text: I'm not quite the fan of regime change that I believe she is.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Martha -- I would just repeat that --

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, I would just repeat that.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Wait a minute.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I think it's only fair to put on the record, Senator Sanders voted in the Senate for a resolution calling for ending the Gadhafi regime and asking that the U.N. be brought in, either a congressional vote or a U.N. Security Council vote.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We got a U.N. Security council vote.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Now, I understand that this is very difficult.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I'm not standing here today and saying that Libya is as far along as Tunisia.

speaker: CLINTON
text: We saw what happened in Egypt.

speaker: CLINTON
text: I cautioned about a quick overthrow of Mubarak, and we now are back with basically an army dictatorship.

speaker: CLINTON
text: This is a part of the world where the United States has tried to play two different approaches.

speaker: CLINTON
text: One, work with the tough men, the dictators, for our own benefit and promote democracy.

speaker: CLINTON
text: That's a hard road to walk.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I think it's the right road for us to try to travel.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And Martha...

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Quick Governor O'Malley.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: ... and in this case, we probably let our lust for regime toppling get ahead of the practical considerations for stability in that region.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And I believe that one of the big failings in that region is a lack of human intelligence.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We have not made the investments that we need to make to understand and to have relationships with future leaders that are coming up.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: That's what Chris Stevens was trying to do.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: But without the tools, without the support that was needed to that.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And now what we have is a whole stretch now, of the coast of Libya, 100 miles, 150 miles, that has now become potentially the next safe haven for ISIL.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: They go back and forth between Syria and this region.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We have to stop contributing to the creation of vacuums that allow safe havens to develop.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you very much.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We're going to move on here.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Governor O'Malley, thank you very much for that.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And we're going to make a very sharp turn as we wrap things up here.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Secretary Clinton, first ladies, as you well know, have used their position to work on important causes like literacy and drug abuse.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: But they also supervise the menus, the flowers, the holiday ornaments and White House decor.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I know you think you know where I'm going here.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You have said that Bill Clinton is a great host and loves giving tours but may opt out of picking flower arrangements if you're elected.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Bill Clinton aside, is it time to change the role of a president's spouse?

speaker: CLINTON
text: Well, the role has been defined by each person who's held it.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I am very grateful for all my predecessors and my successors because each of them not only did what she could to support her husband and our country but often chose to work on important issues that were of particular concern.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Obviously, Mrs. Obama has been a terrific leader when it comes to young people's health, particularly nutrition and exercise.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And I think has had a big impact.

speaker: CLINTON
text: So whoever is part of the family of a president has an extraordinary privilege of not only having a front row seat on history but making her or maybe his contribution.

speaker: CLINTON
text: And with respect to my own husband, I am probably still going to pick the flowers and the china for state dinners and stuff like that.

speaker: CLINTON
text: But I will certainly turn to him as prior presidents have for special missions, for advice, and in particular, how we're going to get the economy working again for everybody, which he knows a little bit about.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CLINTON
text: Democrats discuss presidential spouses.

speaker: CLINTON
text: Candidates Hillary Clinton, Martin O'Malley and Bernie Sanders talk about the roles their spouses would play in helping run the Oval Office (ABC News).

speaker: MUIR
text: I do want to follow up here for each of you.

speaker: MUIR
text: And a similar line of questioning.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator Sanders, your wife Jane shares an office at your campaign headquarters in Burlington.

speaker: MUIR
text: We've seen the pictures, the desks right next to each other.

speaker: MUIR
text: Would she have a desk close by in the west wing?

speaker: SANDERS
text: Given the fact that she's a lot smarter than me, yes, she would.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SANDERS
text: And let me, by the way, take this moment to congratulate Hillary Clinton, who I thought not only did an outstanding job as our first lady, but redefined what that role could be.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So, I thank you very much for that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: SANDERS
text: My wife, Jane, has been -- way back when before I knew her, a foster parent.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Many, many kids came into her home and received the kind of love that they desperately needed.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And she turned around many lives.

speaker: SANDERS
text: She is the best parent and grandmother that I know.

speaker: SANDERS
text: She has devoted her life, when I was mayor of the city of Burlington, actually when I first met her, we started a youth office, which started a after-school programs for kids, started a child care center, started a youth newspaper.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We got the kids involved in a whole lot of issues.

speaker: SANDERS
text: She led that effort.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I think, at a time when so many of our kids are desperately looking for constructive activity, where too many of our kids are hanging around on street corners, potentially getting into trouble, I think we need a forceful advocate for the children, for teenagers, for the little children, to deal with the dysfunctional child care system, and I think my wife would do a great job in helping me accomplish those goals.

speaker: MUIR
text: Senator, thank you.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Well, that would be totally up to her.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: I mean, Katie has never been a person who let her husband's professional choices get in the way of following her dreams.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And I think she got that from her mother, actually.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: The -- and I readily admit that she is a far more accomplished lawyer than I was ever able to become, before I took my detour.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: She is a district court judge in Maryland.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: She puts in a full day there.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: We've raised four terrific kids.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: And yet, when she was first lady of the state, not only would she go to work every day and sit there through a lot of sad and gut-wrenching cases, but then she'd put in additional time being an advocate against domestic violence.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Maryland made great strides on that because of her advocacy, and her understanding of how the court process works.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: She was an advocate against bullying and implementing anti-bullying things.

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: So Katie O'Malley will do whatever Katie O'Malley wants to do, regardless of her husband's success in getting elected president.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor O'Malley, thank you, (inaudible).

speaker: O'MALLEY
text: Thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: Governor, thank you.

speaker: MUIR
text: We'll be back with much more from New Hampshire.

speaker: MUIR
text: The Democratic debate continues right after this.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: MUIR
text: Welcome back tonight.

speaker: MUIR
text: It's been an evening of lively discussion among the candidates and it's time for closing statements.

speaker: MUIR
text: We began in alphabetical order, so we'll reverse the order at the end and begin with you, Senator Sanders.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Well, thank you very much for hosting this debate, and let me applaud my colleagues up here.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Because I think frankly, maybe I'm wrong, but on our worst day, I think we have a lot more to offer the American people than the right wing's extremists.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SANDERS
text: My father came to this country from Poland at the age of 17 without a nickel in his pocket, which sparked my interest in the need for immigration reform because I know what it's like to be the son of an immigrant.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We grew up in a three-and-a-half-room, rent controlled apartment in Brooklyn, New York.

speaker: SANDERS
text: My mother's dream -- and she died very young, but my mother's dream for her whole life was to be able to get out of that rent-controlled apartment and own a home of her own.

speaker: SANDERS
text: She never lived to see that.

speaker: SANDERS
text: But what my parents did accomplish is they were able to send both of their sons to college.

speaker: SANDERS
text: We were the first in the family.

speaker: SANDERS
text: So I know something about economic anxiety and living in a family does not have sufficient income.

speaker: SANDERS
text: And that is why I am pledged, if elected president of the United States, to bring about a political revolution where millions of people begin to stand up and finally say enough is enough, this great country and our government belong to all of us, not just a handful of billionaires.

speaker: SANDERS
text: Thank you very much.

speaker: SYSTEM

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Governor O'Malley?

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Martha, thank you.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I want to thank all of the people who have tuned in tonight.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I want to thank the great people of New Hampshire, where despite all of the cynicism about big money and big banks taking over our politics, here in New Hampshire, the individual matters.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: You know, my wife Katie and I have four terrific kids, and like you, there's probably nothing we wouldn't do to give them a future that's safer, that's healthier, where they have more opportunity than our parents and grandparents gave to us.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Tonight, what you listened to was a healthy exchange of ideas about how we'd do that, that which we have always proven, the capacity to do better than any nation in the world, to take actions that include more of our people more fully in the economic, social and political life of our country.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: When you listened to the Republican debate the other night, you heard a lot of anger and you had a lot of fear.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Well, they can have their anger and they can have their fear, but anger and fear never built America.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We build our country by adopting wage and labor policies, including comprehensive immigration reform with a pathway of citizenship for all.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We do it by investing in our country, by investing in infrastructure, by investing in the skills and the talents of our people with debt-free college, and we can do it again.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: And we also create a better future for our kids when we square our shoulders to the great challenges of our times, whether it's terror trying to undermine our values or Republican presidential candidates trying to get us to surrender our freedoms and our values in the face of this threat.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The other big challenge we have is climate change.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: The greatest business opportunity to come to the United States of America in 100 years.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: We need to embrace this.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: I have put forward a plan that does this, that moves us to 100 percent clean electric grid by 2050.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Join this campaign for the future.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: New leadership is what our country needs to move us out of these divided and polarized times.

speaker: RADDATZ
text: Thank you.

text: There's the establishment lane, the anti- establishment lane, and then there's the Kasich lane.

text: And the reason is, is that I've been a reformer all of my career, fighting to reform welfare, fighting to reform the Pentagon, also being in a position to balance the budget, because that is very, very hard to do.

text: And then in Ohio, of course, I had to bring about big reform, again, because we were so far in the hole and now we just found out we are up over 400,000 jobs since I took over as governor.

text: You know, the situation is this.

speaker: KASICH
text: We cannot fix things in this country -- the Social Security, the border, balancing the budget, getting wages to grow faster -- unless we lead as conservatives, but we also invite people in from the other party.

text: ISIS is the most dangerous jihadist group in the history of mankind.

text: ISIS is a group that burns people alive in cages; that sells off little girls as brides.

text: They want to trigger an apocalyptic Armageddon showdown.

text: This group needs to be confronted and defeated.

text: They're not going to turn into stockbrokers overnight or open up a chain of car washes.

text: They've given out $140 million of bonuses to Veterans Department employees, including reducing the waiting lists, without giving veterans care.
