text: People died, and only three people have been fired.

speaker: BUSH
text: I will make sure that we fire the sheer incompetence inside the Department of Veterans Affairs and then we'll give veterans a choice card so that they don't have to travel hours and hours to get care if they want to go to their private provider.

speaker: BUSH
text: You want to make the Veterans Administration do a better job, give them -- give veterans choices and you'll get a much better result.

speaker: BUSH
text: And as it relates to all the other organizations, let me give you a good example.

speaker: BUSH
text: In Houston, Texas, there's an organization in place because someone acted on their heart, wanted to make sure that there's no homeless veterans in Houston.

speaker: BUSH
text: And they've come pretty close to that without federal government assistance.

speaker: BUSH
text: We need to mobilize the entire country to treat our veterans and treat them with much more respect than they get today.

speaker: BAIER
text: Governor Bush, thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BAIER
text: Speaking of veterans, we have a question from a veteran who is one of the top Youtube creators.

speaker: BAIER
text: Over the course of the evening, gentlemen, we will hear from some of Youtube's most followed stars.

speaker: BAIER
text: And here's one of them.

speaker: QUESTION
text: I'm Mark Watson.

speaker: QUESTION
text: I'm known for my (inaudible) views on Youtube, but I'm also a veteran who served in the Army for eight years.

speaker: QUESTION
text: As an African-American living near Ferguson, I've seen the strain between police officers and the communities they serve firsthand.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Now, there are great tools like body cameras that -- to protect both officers and citizens, but we all currently have better cameras in our pockets than in our precincts.

speaker: QUESTION
text: Why aren't we using the technology available to better protect our communities?

speaker: BAIER
text: Senator Paul, that question to you.

speaker: PAUL
text: You know, I've supported legislation to allow body cameras.

speaker: PAUL
text: I've been to Ferguson, I've been trying to look for solutions to our criminal justice problem.

speaker: PAUL
text: One thing I discovered in Ferguson was that a third of the budget for the city of Ferguson was being reaped by civil fines.

speaker: PAUL
text: People were just being fined to death.

speaker: PAUL
text: Now you and I and many of the people in this audience, if we get a $100 fine, we can survive it.

speaker: PAUL
text: If you're living on the edge of poverty and you get a $100 fine or your car towed, a lot of times you lose your job.

speaker: PAUL
text: I also think the war on drugs has disproportionately affected our African-American community, and what we need to do is make sure that the war on drugs is equal protection under the law and that we don't unfairly incarcerate another generation of young African-American males.

speaker: PAUL
text: In Ferguson, for every 100 African-American women, there are only 60 African-American men.

speaker: PAUL
text: Drug use is about equal between white and black, but our prisons -- three out of four people in prison are black or brown.

speaker: PAUL
text: I think something has to change.

speaker: PAUL
text: I think it's a big thing that our party needs to be part of, and I've been a leader in Congress on trying to bring about criminal justice reform.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BAIER
text: Senator Paul, thank you.

speaker: WALLACE
text: This debate is just getting started.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Coming up, the role of the federal government.

speaker: WALLACE
text: But first, join tonight's conversation right from your home.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Go to google.com or open your Google search app and search Fox News Debate to vote on which issue is most important to you in this election.

speaker: WALLACE
text: More from the Iowa Events Center and the Republican presidential debate in a moment.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

speaker: KELLY
text: Welcome back, everybody.

speaker: KELLY
text: We are live in Des Moines, Iowa.

speaker: KELLY
text: And let's get right back to the questions -- Bret.

speaker: BAIER
text: Thank you, Megyn.

speaker: BAIER
text: Gentlemen, I'll ask you some questions about federal spending and the role of the federal government.

speaker: BAIER
text: Everybody always said they want to cut federal spending and usually they start by saying they'll cut waste, fraud, and abuse, but that really doesn't ever materialize.

speaker: BAIER
text: We all know that.

speaker: BAIER
text: Governor Christie, you talk a lot about entitlement reform and you say that that's where the federal government can get savings needed to balance the budget.

speaker: BAIER
text: But can you name even one thing that the federal government does now that it should not do at all?

speaker: CHRISTIE
text: Yes.

speaker: CHRISTIE
text: You want one?

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: BAIER
text: I want one.

speaker: BAIER
text: Yes.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER)

speaker: CHRISTIE
text: How about one that I've done in New Jersey for the last six years.

speaker: CHRISTIE
text: That's get rid of Planned Parenthood funding from the United States of America.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BAIER
text: Anything bigger than that?

speaker: CHRISTIE
text: Bigger than that?

speaker: CHRISTIE
text: Let me tell you something, when you see thousands upon thousands upon thousands of children being murdered in the womb, I can't think of anything better than that.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BAIER
text: And, Governor, I realize everyone on this stage opposes Obamacare and you're not alone.

speaker: BAIER
text: Google Data shows that in the last month when people searched "policy repeals," that there were a lot of them.

speaker: BAIER
text: Obamacare took the top two spots.

speaker: BAIER
text: But today there are millions of people who gained health insurance from Obamacare and they now rely on it.

speaker: BAIER
text: So the question, Senator Cruz, if you repeal Obamacare, as you say you will, will you be fine if millions of those people don't have health insurance?

speaker: BAIER
text: And what is your specific plan for covering the uninsured?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Sure.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Well, let's take it one at a time.

speaker: CRUZ
text: First of all, we have seen now in six years of Obamacare that it has been a disaster.

speaker: CRUZ
text: It is the biggest job-killer in this country.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Millions of Americans have lost their jobs, have been forced into part-time work, have lost their health insurance, have lost their doctors, have seen their premiums skyrocket.

speaker: CRUZ
text: If I'm elected president, we will repeal every word of Obamacare.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CRUZ
text: Now, once that is done, everyone agrees we need healthcare reform.

speaker: CRUZ
text: It should follow the principles of expanding competition, empowering patients, and keeping government from getting in between us and our doctors.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Three specific reforms that reflect those principles.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Number one, we should allow people to purchase health insurance across state lines.

speaker: CRUZ
text: That will create a true 50-state national marketplace which will drive down the cost of low-cost, catastrophic health insurance.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Number two, we should expand health savings accounts so people can save in a tax-advantaged way for more routine healthcare needs.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And number three, we should work to de-link health insurance from employment so if you lose your job, your health insurance goes with you and it is personal, portable and affordable.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And I'll tell you, Bret, I think that's a much more attractive vision for healthcare than the Washington-drive, top-down Obamacare that is causing so many millions of people to hurt.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BAIER
text: Senator Cruz, thank you.

speaker: BAIER
text: Governor Bush, you've advocated for statehood for Puerto Rico.

speaker: BAIER
text: The Puerto Rican economy is collapsing under unsustainable debt burden.

speaker: BAIER
text: Only about 1 million of its 4 million residents are currently employed.

speaker: BAIER
text: So should American citizens who you say are already overtaxed, bail out Puerto Rico as well?

speaker: BUSH
text: No, they shouldn't.

speaker: BUSH
text: And I believe that Puerto Rico ought to have the right of self-determination.

speaker: BUSH
text: If I was a Puerto Rican, I'd vote for statehood so that they have full citizenship.

speaker: BUSH
text: They serve in the military.

speaker: BUSH
text: They would have to pay federal taxes.

speaker: BUSH
text: They would -- they would accept the responsibilities of full U.S. citizenship.

speaker: BUSH
text: But they should have the right of determine -- self-determination.

speaker: BUSH
text: Before you get to that, though, Puerto Rico is going to have to deal with the structural problems they face.

speaker: BUSH
text: You know, it's -- it's a fact that if you can pay for a $79 one-way ticket to Orlando, and you can escape the challenges of a declining economy and high crime rates, you move to Orlando.

speaker: BUSH
text: And a lot of people are doing that.

speaker: BUSH
text: And the spiraling out-of- control requires Puerto Rico to make structural reforms.

speaker: BUSH
text: The federal government can play a role in allowing them to do that, but they should not -- the process of statehood or the status of Puerto Rico won't be solved until we get to the bigger issue of how you deal with the structural economic problems they're facing right now.

speaker: BAIER
text: Governor Kasich, you're one of two remaining sitting governors still in the race.

speaker: BAIER
text: Your colleague, Governor Rick Snyder of Michigan is under fire -- he and his administration -- for the Flint, Michigan water crisis and the botched response to it.

speaker: BAIER
text: How would you have handled that?

speaker: KASICH
text: Well, you've got to be on top of it right away.

speaker: KASICH
text: And, you know, I don't know all the details of what Rick Snyder has done.

speaker: KASICH
text: I know there have been people who have been fired; people who are being held accountable.

speaker: KASICH
text: But the fact is, every single engine of government has to move when you see a crisis like that.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I've had many situations in the state of Ohio where we've had to move, whether it's storms, whether it was a horrible school shooting.

speaker: KASICH
text: There are many crises that come -- a water crisis in Toledo.

speaker: KASICH
text: You've got to be on top of it.

speaker: KASICH
text: You've got to go the extra mile.

speaker: KASICH
text: You've got to work with local communities and you've got to work with the federal government.

speaker: KASICH
text: Because you realize that people depending on you.

speaker: KASICH
text: And so, you go the extra mile.

speaker: KASICH
text: But people have to be alert.

speaker: KASICH
text: They have to be alert to problems.

speaker: KASICH
text: And when you see a problem, you must act quickly to get on top of it.

speaker: KASICH
text: And people at home are saying they've got a problem, listen to them.

speaker: KASICH
text: Because most of the time, they're absolutely correct.

speaker: KASICH
text: So the fact is that we work for the people.

speaker: KASICH
text: The people don't work for us.

speaker: KASICH
text: And we have to have an attitude when we're in government of serving-hood.

speaker: KASICH
text: That's what really matters.

speaker: KASICH
text: We serve you.

speaker: KASICH
text: You don't serve us.

speaker: KASICH
text: We listen to you and -- and then we act.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BAIER
text: Senator Rubio, on the issue of climate change, in 2008, you wanted Florida to get ahead of other states and establish a cap- and-trade system, a program for carbon emissions, which many Republicans thought at the time would hurt the Florida economy.

speaker: BAIER
text: Now, you're a skeptic of climate change science.

speaker: BAIER
text: And in fact, you warn that federal efforts to fight climate change will cost U.S. jobs and hurt the U.S. economy.

speaker: BAIER
text: So why the change?

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, Bret, first that's not entirely the story.

speaker: RUBIO
text: At the time, the liberal governor of Florida, who claimed he was a Republican -- his name was Charlie Crist -- he wanted to impose cap-and-trade on Florida.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I opposed it.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I was the first person out of the box that opposed him on it.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And then we saw that the leading candidates for president at the time, both the Republican and the Democrats, all supported it.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And what we said is, if they're going to impose this on us, we better prepare to protect the state from it.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But I have never supported cap- and-trade and I never thought it was a good idea.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I was clear about that at the time.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I do not believe it's a good idea now.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I do not believe that we have to destroy our economy in order to protect our environment.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And especially what these programs are asking us to pass that will do nothing to help the environment, but will be devastating for our economy.

speaker: RUBIO
text: When I am president of the United States of America, there will never be any cap-and-trade in the United States.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BAIER
text: Thanks, Senator.

text: All right.

speaker: RUBIO

speaker: RUBIO
text: I am the son and grandson of immigrants.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I know that securing our borders is not anti-immigrant and we will do it.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We'll hire 20,000 new border agents instead of 20,000 new IRS agents.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We will finish the 700 miles of fencing and walls our nation needs.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We'll have mandatory E-verify, a mandatory entry/exit tracking system and until all of that is in place and all of that is working and we can prove to the people of this country that illegal immigration is under control, nothing else is going to happen.

speaker: RUBIO
text: There will be a process.

speaker: RUBIO

speaker: RUBIO

text: A county clerk in Kentucky named Kim Davis refused to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples after the Supreme Court ruling, saying that it violated her religious beliefs.

text: It is because in this nation, we are influenced by Judeo-Christian values that teach us to care for the less fortunate, to reach out to the needy, to love our neighbor.

speaker: RUBIO
text: This is what's made our nation so special.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And you should hope that our next president is someone that is influence by their faith.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Because if your faith causes you to care for the less fortunate, it is something you want to see in your public figures.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And when I'm president, I can tell you this, my faith will not just influence the way I'll govern as president, it will influence the way I live my life.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Because in the end, my goal is not simply to live on this earth for 80 years, but to live an eternity with my creator.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I will always allow my faith to influence everything I do.

text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: WALLACE
text: Thank you, senator.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Senator Paul, in May on the campaign trail you, said you didn't get into politics to fight about abortion.

speaker: WALLACE
text: You said you were more concerned about the national debt.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Your answer is to turn abortion back to the states the way it was before Roe v. Wade.

speaker: WALLACE
text: Does that mean that if a liberal state, let's say, wants to make abortion legal, that you're okay with that and what do you say to conservative voters who believe deeply that abortion is murder?

speaker: PAUL
text: You know, I think abortion is always wrong.

speaker: PAUL
text: I've supported a variety of solutions, both state as well as federal.

speaker: PAUL
text: In fact, just last week, I introduced the Life at Conception act, which would say that the 14th amendment would defend an individual even in the womb.

speaker: PAUL
text: But I think on the broader question of religion and politics, you know, I think liberty, itself requires a virtue -- requires a virtuous people.

speaker: PAUL
text: In fact, Washington said that democracy requires a virtuous people.

speaker: PAUL
text: Oz Guinness, the theologian, said that liberty requires restraint but the only restraint consistent with liberty is self-restraint.

speaker: PAUL
text: There's a lot packed into that statement.

speaker: PAUL
text: But the bottom line is we must have virtue, we must have a religious bearing as a nation.

speaker: PAUL
text: The government is not always going to save us and it's not always going to come from government.

speaker: PAUL
text: But if we don't know right and wrong, I think we have lost our way.

speaker: PAUL
text: I think we become unmoored and I think without the religious foundation that guides us all, I think we have a great risk of going horribly in the wrong direction.

speaker: WALLLACE
text: Sir, just 30 seconds to answer my specific...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: WALLACE

speaker: WALLACE
text: Do you favor the idea that abortion should be a states' rights issue and if a liberal state wants to make it legal, that that's their choice?

speaker: WALLACE
text: Yes or no?

speaker: PAUL
text: Both.

speaker: PAUL
text: No, both the federal and a state approach.

speaker: PAUL
text: I have said that we could leave it to the states but I've also introduced a federal solution as well.

speaker: PAUL
text: So the federal solution would be the Life at Conception act which is an act that would federalize the issue.

speaker: PAUL
text: But I've also said for the most part, these issues would be left back to the states.

speaker: PAUL
text: So there might be an occasion if we did overturn Roe v. Wade -- Roe v. Wade nationalized the issue.

speaker: PAUL
text: If you had the court reverse Roe v. Wade, it would become a state issue once again.

speaker: PAUL
text: I think it would be better the more -- the less abortions we have, so the more states that we have that made abortion illegal, the better, as far as trying to save and preserve lives.

speaker: RUBIO

speaker: RUBIO

speaker: RUBIO

speaker: RUBIO

speaker: CARSON
text: We the people of the United States in order to form a more perfect union, establish justice, ensure domestic tranquility, provide for the common defense, promote the general welfare and secure the benefits of liberty to ourselves and our posterity, do ordain and establish this constitution of the United States of America.

speaker: CARSON
text: Folks, it's not too late.

speaker: CARSON
text: Enough said.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BAIER
text: Florida Senator Marco Rubio.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The bible commands us to let our light shine on the world.

speaker: RUBIO
text: For over 200 years, America's light has been shining on the world and the world has never been the same again.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But now, that light is dimming a little, after seven years of Barack Obama.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And that's why Monday night, what will happen here in Iowa is so important.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I'm asking you for your vote.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Caucus for me on Monday night because if I am your nominee, I will unite this party and I will defeat Hillary Clinton and when I'm president, America's light will shine again and the 21 century will be a new American century.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BAIER
text: Thank you senator.

speaker: KELLY
text: Texas Senator, Ted Cruz.

speaker: KELLY
text: Senator.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Ninety-three hours.

speaker: CRUZ
text: The media noise will soon be over and it's now for the men and women of Iowa to decide.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Our country is in crisis.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We're worried the future of our children and we've have been burned over and over again.

speaker: CRUZ
text: The central question in this race is trust.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Who do you know will kill the terrorists, defend the constitution and repeal Obamacare?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Who do you know will stop amnesty and secure the borders?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Who do you know will defend life, marriage and religious liberty?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Examine our records, pray on it and I will be honored if you and your family will come caucus for us on Monday night.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: KELLY
text: Gentlemen, thank you all so much for being here tonight.

speaker: KELLY
text: We appreciate it greatly.

speaker: KELLY
text: And that does it for the seventh Republican primary debate of the 2016 presidential race.

speaker: KELLY
text: But we're not done.

speaker: KELLY
text: The Kelly file starts in a moment and guess who is going to be there?

speaker: KELLY
text: Senator Ted Cruz.

speaker: WALLACE
text: And don't forget, after all the talk, the first voting of the 2016 campaign happens in just four days.

speaker: WALLACE
text: The first Americans to vote, the Iowa caucuses are Monday and Fox News will have complete coverage.

speaker: BAIER
text: And we have you covered from Iowa, all the way to the conventions and on to the general election.

speaker: BAIER
text: Thanks again for joining us.

speaker: BAIER
text: For all of us here in Des Moines, have a great evening.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Live from the Bank United Center on the campus of the University of Miami, this is the CNN Republican Presidential debate.

speaker: TAPPER
text: For our viewers in the United States and around the world, welcome to Miami Florida, I'm Jake Tapper.

speaker: TAPPER
text: In just five days voters will go to the polls here in this state as well as in Ohio, Illinois, North Carolina and Missouri.

speaker: TAPPER
text: The race for the Republican nomination for president could change dramatically.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Florida and Ohio each have a large number of delegates at stake and they award all of them to the candidate who wins.

speaker: TAPPER
text: They're a winner-take-all state.

speaker: TAPPER
text: So that's the first time that will happen in this primary season and this is the last debate before that critical round of voting.

speaker: TAPPER
text: We hope tonight the candidates will give the voters specifics on their visions for America.

speaker: TAPPER
text: So now let's welcome the candidates.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Ohio Governor John Kasich.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Real estate developer and businessman Donald Trump.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Ladies and gentlemen, the Republican candidates for president of the United States.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Before we begin this evening, we want to remember former first lady Nancy Reagan, who passed away this week.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Her funeral will be held tomorrow and we would like to take a moment of silence to remember Nancy Reagan.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (MOMENT OF SILENCE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Now, please rise for our national anthem performed by the Frost Singers from the University of Miami.

speaker: TAPPER
text: (STAR SPANGLED BANNER)

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Thanks to the Frost Singers from the University of Miami.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Candidates, you can now take your positions behind the podiums while I briefly explain the rules.

speaker: TAPPER
text: As moderator, I will attempt to guide the discussion, asking questions and followups.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Joining me in the questioning this evening will be Washington Times reporter Stephen Dinan, CNN Chief Political Correspondent Dana Bash, and Salem Radio's Hugh Hewitt.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Candidates, you have one minute and 15 seconds to answer each question, and 45 seconds to respond to followups or for rebuttals if your name is invoked.

speaker: TAPPER
text: That's longer than you've had in previous debates.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Timing lights will be visible.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Those lights will warn you when time is up.

speaker: TAPPER
text: And as you requested, a bell will also sound, like this.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (BELL SOUND)

speaker: TAPPER
text: We know that each of you wants to debate these important issues, but please wait until you are called upon and please do not talk over one another.

speaker: TAPPER
text: These are the rules to which all of you agreed.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Our goal this evening is a serious debate on the issues.

speaker: TAPPER
text: It's time now for opening statements.

speaker: TAPPER
text: You'll each have 30 seconds.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Governor Kasich, we will start with you.

speaker: KASICH
text: Well, thank you.

speaker: KASICH
text: You know, I look in the faces of people all across this country, and I know they want to be hopeful.

speaker: KASICH
text: And many are hopeful.

speaker: KASICH
text: Look, I can take conservative policies to the White House, to Washington, to restore the strength of our economy.

speaker: KASICH
text: But I also want to transfer power, money and influence to where you live, because I believe the strength in this country rests in the neighborhoods, the families, the communities and our states.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I believe it's a new partnership - a partnership that can allow us to restore the spirit of America and strengthen America for the best century we've ever had.

speaker: KASICH
text: Thank you.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Senator Rubio?

speaker: RUBIO
text: Every election is important.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I believe this is the most important election in a generation.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Because what's at stake in this election is not simply what party is going to be in charge or which candidate wins.

speaker: RUBIO
text: What's at stake is our identity as a nation and as a people.

speaker: RUBIO
text: For over two centuries, America has been an exceptional nation.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And now the time has come for this generation to do what it must do to keep it that way.

speaker: RUBIO
text: If we make the right choice in this election, our children are going to be the freest and most prosperous Americans that have ever lived.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And the 21st century is going to be a new American century.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Senator Cruz?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Fifty-nine years ago, Florida welcomed my father to America as he stepped off the ferry boat from Cuba onto Key West.

speaker: CRUZ
text: He was 18.

speaker: CRUZ
text: He was filled with hopes and dreams, and yet he was in the freest land on the face of the earth.

speaker: CRUZ
text: This election, this debate is not about insults.

speaker: CRUZ
text: It's not about attacks.

speaker: CRUZ
text: It's not about any of the individuals on this stage.

speaker: CRUZ
text: This election is about you and your children.

speaker: CRUZ
text: It's about the freedom America has always had and making sure that that freedom is there for the next generation, that we stop Washington from standing in the way of the hard-working taxpayers of America.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Mr. Trump?

speaker: TRUMP
text: One of the biggest political events anywhere in the world is happening right now with the Republican Party.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Millions and millions of people are going out to the polls and they're voting.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're voting out of enthusiasm.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They're voting out of love.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Some of these people, frankly, have never voted before - 50 years old, 60 years old, 70 years old - never voted before.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're taking people from the Democrat Party.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're taking people as independents, and they're all coming out and the whole world is talking about it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's very exciting.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think, frankly, the Republican establishment, or whatever you want to call it, should embrace what's happening.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're having millions of extra people join.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are going to beat the Democrats.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We are going to beat Hillary or whoever it may be.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we're going to beat them soundly.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Thank you.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Thank you.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Let's begin with jobs and the economy, which Republican voters say is the most important issue to them in this election.

speaker: TAPPER
text: There have been some real differences expressed in - on this stage on whether trade deals have been good for the American workers.

speaker: TAPPER
text: One of Mr. Trump's, the front runner's, signature issues is ending what he calls "disastrous trade deals" in order to bring jobs back to America.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Governor Kasich, I'd like to start with you.

speaker: TAPPER
text: You've been a strong advocate for these trade deals over the years.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Critics say these deals are great for corporate America's bottom line, but have cost the U.S. at least 1 million jobs.

speaker: TAPPER
text: How do you respond to the criticism that you've been catering to board rooms at the expense of the American middle class?

speaker: KASICH
text: Well, Jake, I grew up in a blue collar family.

speaker: KASICH
text: And the simple fact of the matter is that of course we're sensitive about trade.

speaker: KASICH
text: One out of five Americans works in a job connected to trade; 38 million Americans are connected to it.

speaker: KASICH
text: But my position has always been we want to have free trade, but fair trade.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I've been arguing all along that it is absolutely critical that when other countries break those agreements, we don't turn the process over to some international bureaucrat who comes back a couple years later and says, "Oh, America was right," and people are out of work.

speaker: KASICH
text: The fact of the matter is we have to have an expedited process.

speaker: KASICH
text: When people cheat, when countries cheat and they take advantage of us, we need to blow the whistle.

speaker: KASICH
text: And as president of the United States, I absolutely will blow the whistle and begin to stand up for the American worker.

speaker: KASICH
text: But we don't want to lock the doors and pull down the blinds and leave the world.

speaker: KASICH
text: Because frankly, if we do that, prices will go up.

speaker: KASICH
text: People will buy less.

speaker: KASICH
text: Other people will be out of work.

speaker: KASICH
text: And we don't want to see that happen.

speaker: KASICH
text: Trade, though, has to be balanced and we have to make sure that when we see a violation, like some country dumping their products into this country, believe me as president, I will stand up and I will shut down those imports because they're a violation of the agreement we have and the American worker expects us to stand up.

speaker: KASICH
text: And Jake, my family worked in the steel industry, not with a white collar.

speaker: KASICH
text: I understand their plight.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Mr. Trump, your critics say your campaign platform is inconsistent with how you run your businesses, noting that you've brought in foreign workers instead of hiring Americans, and your companies manufacture clothing in China and Mexico.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Why should voters trust that you will run the country differently from how you run your businesses?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because nobody knows the system better than me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know the H1B.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I know the H2B.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody knows it better than me.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'm a businessman.

speaker: TRUMP
text: These are laws.

speaker: TRUMP
text: These are regulations.

speaker: TRUMP
text: These are rules.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're allowed to do it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And frankly, because of the devaluations that other countries - the monetary devaluations that other countries are constantly doing and brilliantly doing against us, it's very, very hard for our companies in this country, in our country, to compete.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I will take advantage of it; they're the laws.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I'm the one that knows how to change it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Nobody else on this dais knows how to change it like I do, believe me.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Senator Rubio, last October, you said that you're, quote, "generally very much in favor of free trade."

speaker: TAPPER
text: More recently, you backed a away from your support of some trade deals.

speaker: TAPPER
text: If elected, will you support free trade deals even if it means the inevitable loss of U.S. jobs?

speaker: RUBIO
text: No, I support free trade deals that are good for America.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We're 5 percent of the world's population.

speaker: RUBIO
text: If all we do is sell things to each other, we can only sell to 5 percent of the people on earth.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We have to have access to the hundreds of millions of people in the world today who can afford to buy things.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The problem is we're a low-tariff country.

speaker: RUBIO
text: To import something into the United States is not very expensive, but many of these countries we can't export to because their tariffs are too high.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And so I am in favor of deals that allow us to bring down those tariffs so that America can sell things to all these people around the world.

speaker: RUBIO
text: There are good trade deals and there are bad ones.

speaker: RUBIO
text: So for example, here in Florida, we have benefited from the free trade deal with Colombia.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It's allowed flower exporters to come into the United States but it's created jobs for hundreds of people who are now delivering those flowers and working in that industry.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We have a surplus with Colombia.

speaker: RUBIO
text: On the other hand, you've seen trade deals like in Mexico that have been less than promising in some aspects, better in others.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Bottom line is I believe that America, if given access to foreign markets, our workers are the most productive in the world, our people are the most innovative on this planet.

speaker: RUBIO
text: If it is a free and fair trade deal, we can compete against anyone in the world, and we need to in the 21st century.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Senator Cruz, you were a supporter of the Pacific trade deal, but after taking some heat from conservatives, you changed your position.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Why should these voters who don't like these trade deals trust that you will fight for them all the time and not just in election years?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Actually that's incorrect.

speaker: CRUZ
text: There are two different agreements.

speaker: CRUZ
text: There's TPA and TPP.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I opposed TPP and have always opposed TPP, which is what you asked about.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And when it comes to trade, look, free trade, when we open up foreign markets, helps Americans.

speaker: CRUZ
text: But we're getting killed in international trade right now.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And we're getting killed because we have an administration that's doesn't look out for American workers and jobs are going overseas.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We're driving jobs overseas.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And the people who are losing out are in manufacturing jobs, or the steel industry or the auto industry.

speaker: CRUZ
text: But I'll tell you who else is going to be losing out, which is the service industry.

speaker: CRUZ
text: This Obama administration is negotiating the Trade in Services Agreement which is another treaty to allow services to come in and take jobs from Americans as well.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And you've got to understand.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Trade and immigration are interwoven, and they are hurting the working men and women of this country.

speaker: CRUZ
text: So the question is, what's the solution?

speaker: CRUZ
text: It's easy to talk about the problems.

speaker: CRUZ
text: But do you have a solution to fix it?

speaker: CRUZ
text: And I think the solution is several things.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Number one, we need to negotiate trade deals protecting American workers first, not the corporate board room.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Number two, we need to lift the regulations on American businesses here so we see jobs coming back.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And number three, we need a tax plan like the tax plan I've introduced that will not tax exports and that will tax imports, and that will bring millions of high-paying jobs back to America.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Let's talk more about how American jobs are impacted by foreign workers.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Let's go to Stephen Dinan of the Washington Times.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Stephen.

speaker: DINAN
text: Senator Rubio in late 2014, Disney laid off 250 tech workers in Orlando, replacing many of them with foreign workers.

speaker: DINAN
text: Some of the Americans even had to train their own replacements.

speaker: DINAN
text: You support increasing the H-1B visa program that made it possible to bring in these foreign workers.

speaker: DINAN
text: Doesn't this program take jobs away from Americans?

speaker: RUBIO
text: If it's being abused the way Disney did.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Understand that program, it is illegal now under that program to use it to replace American workers.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Under that program, you have to prove not only that you're not replacing Americans, but that you've tried to hire Americans.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And if a company is caught abusing that process, they should never be allowed to use it again.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The second problem with the current structure of the program that people perhaps don't understand is a lot of these companies are not directly hiring employees from abroad.

speaker: RUBIO
text: They are hiring a consulting company like Tata, for example, out of India.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That company then hoards up all of these visas.

speaker: RUBIO
text: They hire workers.

speaker: RUBIO
text: You hire - Disney or some other company hires this company.

speaker: RUBIO
text: What they're basically doing is they are insourcing and outsourcing.

speaker: RUBIO
text: They are bringing in workers from abroad that are not direct employees of a Disney or someone else, they're employees of this consulting business.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And what I argue is that no consulting business such as that should be allowed to hoard up all of these visas, that the visas should only be available for companies to use to directly hire workers and that we should be stricter in how he enforce it.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It is illegal now, it is a violation of the law now to use that program to replace Americans.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And if a company is caught doing that, whether it be Disney or anyone else, they should be barred from using the program in the future.

speaker: DINAN
text: Senator Rubio, real quick follow-up on this.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: DINAN
text: You've - in the - in the context of illegal immigration, you've called for basically putting off any legalization process until we get the border secured.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Correct.

speaker: DINAN
text: Why not call for a pause on H1Bs until those abuses you've talked about are solved.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well first, I think - well, I'd be open to it if it takes a pause.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But I don't think it takes a pause to enforce the law.

speaker: RUBIO
text: What they are doing is they are in fact using that program to replace an American.

speaker: RUBIO
text: If there's an American working at Disney and they bring someone from another country using H1B to replace their direct job, that's in violation of the law.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And what I'm explaining to you is, what they are doing now is they are not - what they are doing is they are eliminating the job.

speaker: RUBIO
text: They are outsourcing the entire tech division to a consulting company.

speaker: RUBIO
text: They are making the argument that we didn't replace you.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We just replaced the whole unit by hiring a company to do it instead.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And that company that they're hiring is bringing their workers from abroad.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It's a loophole they've figured out that we need to close so they can no longer continue to do it that way.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: DINAN
text: Governor Kasich, I want to come to you next.

speaker: DINAN
text: Mr. Trump says that legal immigration is producing quote, "lower wages and higher unemployment for U.S. workers".

speaker: DINAN
text: He's calling for a pause on green cards issued to foreign workers.

speaker: DINAN
text: Wouldn't that help workers in the U.S.?

speaker: KASICH
text: Well look, I believe in immigration, but it has to be controlled.

speaker: KASICH
text: The simple fact of the matter is I wouldn't be standing here.

speaker: KASICH
text: I'd be maybe running for president of Croatia if we didn't have immigration.

speaker: KASICH
text: Immigration is something that brings youth and vibrance and energy to our country.

speaker: KASICH
text: But we clearly have to control our borders.

speaker: KASICH
text: We can't have people just walking in.

speaker: KASICH
text: Look, we lock our doors at night in our homes.

speaker: KASICH
text: The country has to be able to lock its doors as well.

speaker: KASICH
text: So, we - I have a comprehensive plan to deal with this problem of immigration.

speaker: KASICH
text: I would say we have to absolutely finish the wall and guard the border.

speaker: KASICH
text: And if anybody were to come in after that, they are going to have to go back.

speaker: KASICH
text: No excuses because we can't continue this problem.

speaker: KASICH
text: I think we ought to have a guest worker program, where people come in, work and go home.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I think at the same time, for the 11 and a half million who are here, then in my view if they have not committed a crime since they've been here, they get a path to legalization.

speaker: KASICH
text: Not to citizenship.

speaker: KASICH
text: I believe that program can pass the Congress in the first 100 days.

speaker: KASICH
text: But let's not lose sight of the fact that the whole key to the future of America is strong economic growth with common sense regulation, lower taxes and a balanced budget.

speaker: KASICH
text: We can have a rising tide that lifts all the workers in America, all the people who are citizens of America, if we'll just follow the formula that works, that I used in Washington.

speaker: KASICH
text: And guess what, I've used it in Ohio to grow over 400 private sector jobs since I've been governor

speaker: DINAN
text: Mr. Trump, I do want to come to you.

speaker: DINAN
text: Will you also in your answer, address how long you think that pause would be and what that pause would look like.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will.

speaker: TRUMP
text: First of all, I think and I know the H1B very well.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And it's something that I frankly use and I shouldn't be allowed to use it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We shouldn't have it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Very, very bad for workers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And second of all, I think it's very important to say, well, I'm a businessman and I have to do what I have to do.

speaker: TRUMP
text: When it's sitting there waiting for you, but it's very bad.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It's very bad for business in terms of - and it's very bad for our workers and it's unfair for our workers.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we should end it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Very importantly, the Disney workers endorsed me, as you probably read.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I got a full endorsement because they are the ones that said, and they had a news conference, and they said, he's the only one that's going to be able to fix it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Because it is a mess.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think for a period of a year to two years we have to look back and we have to see, just to answer the second part of your question, where we are, where we stand, what's going on.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to sort of take a strong, good, hard look and come up with plans that work.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we're rushing into things, and we're just - we're leading with the chin.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (BELL RINGS)

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're leading with people that don't know what they are doing in terms of our leadership.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I'd say a minimum of one year, maybe two years.

speaker: DINAN
text: Senator Cruz, I want to bring you in very quickly on this.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: DINAN
text: The United States averages about a million new permanent legal immigrants a year and hundreds of thousands more guest workers.

speaker: DINAN
text: What should the right level be?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Well, we need to redefine our legal immigration system so that it meets the needs of the American economy.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Right now, we're bringing in far too many low skilled workers.

speaker: CRUZ
text: What that is doing is driving down the wages of hard-working Americans.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Our system isn't working.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And then on top of that, we've got a system that's allowing in millions of people to be here illegally.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And the answer to that, I've laid out a very, very detailed immigration plan on my website.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We're going to build a wall, triple the border patrol.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We're going to end sanctuary cities.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And let me tell you how we're going to do that.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We're going to cut off federal taxpayer funds to any city that defies federal immigration laws.

speaker: SYSTEM

text: But I will tell you, I think if we're going to ever negotiate a peace settlement, which every Israeli wants, and I've spoken to the toughest and the sharpest, they all want peace, I think it would be much more helpful is - I'm a negotiator.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If I go in, I'll say I'm pro-Israel and I've told that to everybody and anybody that would listen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I would like to at least have the other side think I'm somewhat neutral as to them, so that we can maybe get a deal done.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Maybe we can get a deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think it's probably the toughest negotiation of all time.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But maybe we can get a deal done.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Senator Trump...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TRUMP
text: And, by the way, just so you understand, as far as Iran, I would have never made that deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think it's maybe the world deal I've ever seen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think it's the worst deal I've ever seen negotiated.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I will be so tough on them and ultimately that deal will be broken unless they behave better than they've ever behaved in their lives, which is probably unlikely.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That deal will be broken.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Thank you Mr. Trump.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Senator Cruz and Senator Rubio.

speaker: CRUZ
text: You know, we need a president who understands the national security interests of this country.

speaker: CRUZ
text: The reason we are friends and allies with Israel is they are a liberal Democratic country that share our values, they're our strongest ally in the region.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We get billions in intelligence resources, billions in military resources.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And the Palestinian Authority that Donald, along with Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama say they want to treat neutrally, the same as Israel.

speaker: CRUZ
text: The Palestinian Authority is in a unity government with Hamas, a terrorist organization.

speaker: CRUZ
text: They pay the families of these terrorists who murder people.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And this is exactly the moral relativism Barack Obama has.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And the answer is not scream, all Muslims bad.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Let me give you an example of a Muslim for example, we ought to be standing with, President el-Sisi of Egypt, a president of a Muslim country who is targeting radical...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (BELL RINGS)

speaker: CRUZ
text: ... Islamic terrorist.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Senator Rubio.

speaker: CRUZ
text: He's hunting them down and stomping them.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Thank you.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Our focus needs to be on keeping this country safe.

speaker: HEWITT
text: I want to go back to the Israeli government's assertion that the Palestinian Authority is inciting the convulsion of violence.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Do you agree.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, that's undeniable.

speaker: RUBIO
text: First of all, they've said, they've encouraged people to do so.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And you've seen the speeches of the Palestinian Authority president how glorious this is that they're doing these sorts of things.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But let me go back for a moment.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The policy Donald has outlined, I don't know if he realizes, is an anti-Israeli policy.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Maybe that's not your intent but here's why it is an anti-Israeli policy.

speaker: RUBIO
text: There is no peace deal possible with the Palestinians at this moment.

speaker: RUBIO
text: There just isn't.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RUBIO
text: Because there's no one to negotiate with.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The Palestinian Authority is not interested in a serious deal and they are now in union with Hamas, an organization whose specific purpose is the destruction of the Jewish state.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Every time that Israel has turned over territory of any kind, be is Gaza, or now in Judea and Sumaira, it is used as a launching pad to attack Israel.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And that's what will happen again.

speaker: RUBIO
text: These groups are not interested in a deal with Israel.

speaker: RUBIO
text: What they are interested in is ultimately removing the Jewish state and occupying its entire territory.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (BELL RINGS)

speaker: RUBIO
text: So maybe in 30 years the conditions will exist, but they do not exist now.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Trump, and then I'll come to you Senator Kasich.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And To have a president forcing the Israelis to the table is harmful to the Israeli and emboldens Israel's enemies.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Thank you senator.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Trump a response and then we'll go to Governor Kasich.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If I become president of the United States, one of the things that will be an absolute priority is number one, protection of Israel, but also seeing if a deal can be made, the toughest deal, the toughest negotiation there probably is of any kind no matter where you look, no matter how hard you look.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I would like to give it a shot.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Very, very pro-Israel, nobody more pro-Israel.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But I would love to give it a shot.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I have to tell you this, Hugh.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I have friend, Israelis, non-Israelis, people from New York City that happen to be Jewish and love Israel, and some are very tough people, every single one of them, they know it's tough, but every single one of them wants to see if we could ever have peace in Israel.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And some believe it's possible.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It may not be, in which case we'll find out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But it would be a priority if I become president to see what I could do.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Governor Kasich, do you agree the Israeli government that the Palestinian Authority is inciting this violence?

speaker: KASICH
text: Well, there's no question.

speaker: KASICH
text: They were saying that the Israelis intended to go to the Dome of the Rock.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I mean, when you think about this, thank goodness we work with Israelis to give them the Iron Dome where they can protect themselves against all the missiles that were flying in.

speaker: KASICH
text: Could you imagine living in like Miami here and having people shooting missiles in?

speaker: KASICH
text: Secondly, there was just an article the other day, Hugh, that I know you're familiar with the Israelis are learning to train underground in combat because the Palestinians now, Hamas in particular, is digging these tunnels trying to get under Israel.

speaker: KASICH
text: They're coming at them from above, they're trying to come at them under the ground.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I just have to tell you this, I don't believe there is any long-term permanent peace solution.

speaker: KASICH
text: And I think pursuing that is the wrong thing to do.

speaker: KASICH
text: I believe that every day that we can stability in that region by supporting the Israelis and making sure they have the weapons and the security that they need with our 100 percent backing is the way to proceed in the Middle East in regard to Israel.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HEWITT
text: Thank you, Governor.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Senator Cruz, I want to stay in the region.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Just this week the head of U.S. Central Command, General General Lloyd Austin, essentially said it's going to take a lot more troops on the ground to fix - to end the ISIS threat in Syria and Iraq.

speaker: HEWITT
text: From the beginning of this campaign, you have said you will follow the judgment of military commanders in the Pentagon.

speaker: HEWITT
text: So here's the commander saying we need a lot more troops on the ground.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Will you follow that advice and inject Americans again into what is in essence is metastasizing Sunni-Shia civil war?

speaker: CRUZ
text: We need to do whatever is necessary to utterly defeat ISIS.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And that's needs to be driven not by politicians but by military expertise and judgment.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Right now we're not using a fraction of the tools that we have.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We're not using our overwhelming air power.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We're not arming the Kurds.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Those need to be the first steps.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And then we need to put whatever ground power is needed to carry it out.

speaker: CRUZ
text: But, you know, a question that actually Jake asked, and I'm glad to come back to it now, is rules of engagement.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We have right now our troops engaged in combat but President Obama has rules of engagement that are so strict that their arms are tied behind their back.

speaker: CRUZ
text: They're not able to fight.

speaker: CRUZ
text: They're not able to defend themselves.

speaker: CRUZ
text: They're not able to kill the enemy.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And I have got to tell you, Hugh, I think that is wrong.

speaker: CRUZ
text: It is immoral.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And I give my word to every soldier, sailor, and airman, and marine, and every wife and husband, every son and daughter, every mother and father, that will end in January 2017.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: HEWITT
text: Governor Kasich, if it takes 20,000 or 30,000, if the Pentagon says that's what needs to be done, will you follow their advice?

speaker: KASICH
text: Hugh, I've said all along and laid out my foreign policy, I'm going to remind everybody that 55 percent of the foreign policy experts in this country said I was the best to be commander-in- chief.

speaker: KASICH
text: I spent 18 years on the Defense Committee, Armed Services, and then I was in the Pentagon with Donald Rumsfeld after 9/11, in and out for a couple of years.

speaker: KASICH
text: We absolutely have to win this with a coalition.

speaker: KASICH
text: Arabs have to be with us.

speaker: KASICH
text: The Europeans have to understand that this threat is closer to them than even is closer - is as close as it is to us.

speaker: KASICH
text: And in addition to that, you have to be in the air and you have to be on the ground.

speaker: KASICH
text: And you bring all the force you need.

speaker: KASICH
text: It has got to be "shock and awe" in the military-speak.

speaker: KASICH
text: Then once it gets done, and we will wipe them out, once it gets done, it settles down, we come home and let the regional powers redraw the map if that's what it takes.

speaker: HEWITT
text: Mr. Trump, more troops?

speaker: TRUMP
text: We really have no choice.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to knock out ISIS.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to knock the hell out of them.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to get rid of it.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And then come back and rebuild our country, which is falling apart.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have no choice.

speaker: HEWITT
text: How many...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (CROSSTALK)

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would listen to the generals, but I'm hearing numbers of 20,000 to 30,000.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to knock them out fast.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Look, we're not allowed to fight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We can't fight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We're not knocking out the oil because they don't want to create environmental pollution up in the air.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I mean, these are things that nobody even believes.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They think we're kidding.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They didn't want to knock out the oil because of what it's going to do to the carbon footprint.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We don't fight like we used to fight.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We used to fight to win.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Now we fight for no reason whatsoever.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We don't even know what we're doing.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: So, the answer is we have to knock them out.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to knock them out fast.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have to get back home.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And we have to rebuild our country which is falling apart.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Thank you, Mr. Trump.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Let's turn from current conflicts to those who have served in conflicts.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Senator Rubio, according to a V.A. study, of the 22 veterans who commit suicide every day, 17 of them have no connection to the V.A.

speaker: TAPPER
text: The V.A. believes that this lack of connection is one of the reasons for this tragically high suicide rate.

speaker: TAPPER
text: What specifically would you do as president to make sure that veterans in crisis are able to get the help they need?

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, first let me say that one out of four calls to our office is about a veteran here in Florida that's struggling with the V.A.

speaker: RUBIO
text: my brother is a veteran.

speaker: RUBIO
text: He's struggling with the V.A.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The other day, we heard this horrible story.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It was a headline in USA Today, and it said, "Calls to the V.A. Suicide Hotline Went to Voicemail."

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, about a few days ago, we now found out that one of the gentlemen - one of the veterans who left a voicemail committed suicide.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And they happened to call him back the day after he died.

speaker: RUBIO
text: People need to be held accountable for this.

speaker: RUBIO
text: One of the things I'm proudest of is that in my time in the U.S. Senate working with Jeff Miller here from Florida in a bipartisan way, and I'll give him credit - Bernie Sanders was a part of this - we passed a V.A. accountability bill.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And what it did is it created now a law that gives the V.A. secretary, because of the law I passed, it gives the V.A. secretary the power to fire people that aren't doing a good job.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Senior executives should be held accountable if the V.A. outreach isn't working.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The problem is no one's being held accountable.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Even after we passed that law, no one's been fired for no outreach.

speaker: RUBIO
text: No one's been fired for calls going to the voicemail.

speaker: RUBIO
text: No one's been disciplined.

speaker: RUBIO
text: No one's been demoted.

speaker: RUBIO
text: When I'm president of the United States, if you work at the V.A. and you are not doing a good job, you will be fired from your job at the V.A.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Governor Kasich, the Veterans Affairs Department is one of the biggest line items in the domestic budget.

speaker: TAPPER
text: As part of its attempt to cut costs, the Republican-controlled House of Representatives just voted to try to reduce spending in the post-9/11 GI Bill.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Should veterans' benefits be part of attempts to reduce the deficit?

speaker: KASICH
text: I don't - I haven't seen the provisions of that bill, Jake.

speaker: KASICH
text: My initial instincts are no.

speaker: KASICH
text: And let me just say about the V.A.

speaker: KASICH
text: When a veteran comes home, they ought to have access to healthcare wherever they want to go at any time, number one.

speaker: KASICH
text: Number two, the Veterans Administration needs to be restructured.

speaker: KASICH
text: It needs to be downsized and spread out.

speaker: KASICH
text: It needs to be so responsive to the needs of the veterans.

speaker: KASICH
text: And secondly, the Pentagon needs to share the information of returning veterans with the veterans' service operations in the states and with the job people in the states so that when a veteran comes home, they can be linked with a job.

speaker: KASICH
text: And when that happens, that means that every veteran will get work, because they're our golden employees.

speaker: KASICH
text: No veteran ought to be without healthcare; no veteran ought to be homeless; and no veteran ought to be unemployed in the United States of America.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Thank you, Governor Kasich.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TAPPER
text: Let's turn to another issue of real importance here in Florida.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Just over a week from now, President Obama will visit Cuba, the first time in 88 years that a sitting U.S. president will set foot in Cuba.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Two of you on this stage have parents who were born in Cuba and moved to the United States.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Let's go back to my colleague Dana Bash.

speaker: BASH
text: Senator Rubio, Donald Trump agrees with President Obama in his decision to reengage diplomatically in Cuba.

speaker: BASH
text: The majority of Americans seem to agree with that as well.

speaker: BASH
text: So why are President Obama, Donald Trump and the majority of Americans wrong?

speaker: RUBIO
text: Well, I would love the relationship between Cuba and the United States to change.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But it will require Cuba to change, at least its government.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Today, it has not.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The fact of the matter is that after these changes were made - after these changes were made, there are now millions and hundreds of millions of dollars that will flow to the Castro regime.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It will now allow them to become set permanent and in stone.

speaker: RUBIO
text: They will now be able to carry out a transition where the military continues to run the country there.

speaker: RUBIO
text: They'll put a puppet figure forward as their new president.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And nothing will change for the Cuban people.

speaker: RUBIO
text: There has not been a single democratic opening; not a single change on the island in human rights.

speaker: RUBIO
text: In fact, things are worse than they were before this opening.

speaker: RUBIO
text: The only thing that's changed as a result of this opening is that now the Cuban government has more sources of money from which to build out their repressive apparatus and maintain themselves there permanently.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And we asked nothing in return.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Compare that to the changes that were required in Burma.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And by no means is Burma a perfect country.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But at least when there was a democratic opening to Burma, they were required to make some democratic openings.

speaker: RUBIO
text: When there was a diplomatic opening, it required democratic opening.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And today, the former minority party is now the majority party in their legislative body.

speaker: RUBIO
text: He asked nothing in return and we are getting nothing in return.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And Cuba and its regime remains an anti-American communist dictatorship, helped North Korea evade U.N. sanctions.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It's harboring fugitives of American justice, including people stealing our Medicare money and moving back to Cuba, all in exchange for nothing.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BASH
text: Mr. Trump, you said the concept of opening Cuba is fine.

speaker: BASH
text: You said the concept of opening Cuba is fine.

speaker: BASH
text: Why do you agree with President Obama and disagree with what Senator Rubio just said?

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, I don't really agree with President Obama.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I think I'm somewhere in the middle.

speaker: TRUMP
text: What I want is I want a much better deal to be made because right now, Cuba is making - as usual with our country, we don't make good deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We don't have our right people negotiating, we have people that don't have a clue.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As an example, I heard recently where the threat was made that they want reparations for years of abuse by the United States, and nobody's talking about it and they'll end up signing a deal and then we'll get sued for $400 billion or $1 trillion.

speaker: TRUMP
text: All that stuff has to be agreed to now.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We don't want to get sued after the deal is made.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I don't agree with President Obama, I do agree something should be - should take place.

speaker: TRUMP
text: After 50 years, it's enough time, folks.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But we have to make a good deal and we have to get rid of all the litigation that's going to happen.

speaker: TRUMP
text: This was just a little story but it was a big story to me because I said oh, here we go, we make a deal, then get sued for a tremendous amount of money for reparations.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So I want to do something, but it's got to be done intelligently.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We have to make good deal.

speaker: BASH
text: Senator Rubio, I know you want to get in.

speaker: BASH
text: But just to be clear, Mr. Trump, are you saying that if you were president, you would continue the diplomatic relations or would you reverse them?

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would want to make a good deal, I would want to make a strong, solid, good deal because right now, everything is in Cuba's favor.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Right now, everything, every single aspect of this deal is in Cuba's favor.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It the same way as the Iran deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We never walked - we never - all we do is keep giving.

speaker: TRUMP
text: We give and give and give.

speaker: BASH
text: But Mr. Trump, just to be clear, there is an embassy that you would have to decide whether it would be open or whether you would close it.

speaker: BASH
text: Which would it be?

speaker: BASH
text: In Havana.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I would probably have the embassy closed until such time as a really good deal was made and struck by the United States.

speaker: TRUMP
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RUBIO
text: All right, first of all, the embassy is the former consulate.

speaker: RUBIO
text: It's the same building.

speaker: RUBIO
text: So it could just go back to being called a consulate.

speaker: RUBIO
text: We don't have to close it that way.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Second of all, I don't know where Cuba is going to use, but if they sue us in a court in Miami, they're going to lose.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (LAUGHTER AND APPLAUSE)

speaker: RUBIO
text: Third, on the issue of a good deal, I know what the good deal.

speaker: RUBIO
text: I'll tell you what the good deal now, it's already codified.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Here's a good deal - Cuba has free elections, Cuba stops putting people in jail for speaking out, Cuba has freedom of the press, Cuba kicks out the Russians from Lourdes (ph) and kicks out the Chinese listening station in Berupal (ph) Cuba stops helping North Korea evade U.N. sanctions, Cuba takes all of those fugitives of America justice, including that cop killer from New Jersey, and send her back to the United States and to jail where she belongs.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And you know what?

speaker: RUBIO
text: Then we can have a relationship with Cuba.

speaker: RUBIO
text: That's a good deal.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BASH
text: Thank you, Senator Rubio.

speaker: BASH
text: Senator Cruz, if you become president, would you reverse course and once again break diplomatic relations with Cuba?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Yes, I would.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And you know, I think this exchange actually highlights a real choice for Republican primary voters.

speaker: CRUZ
text: When it comes to foreign policy, do you want to continue on the same basic trajectory as the last seven years of the Obama foreign policy?

speaker: CRUZ
text: When it comes to these deals, Cuba and Iran, they were negotiated by Hillary Clinton and John Kerry.

speaker: CRUZ
text: There's a real difference between us.

speaker: CRUZ
text: Donald supported Hillary Clinton and John Kerry.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And what he said right now is that he agrees in principle with what they're doing.

speaker: CRUZ
text: The only thing he thinks is that they should negotiate a little bit better deals, they should be more effective.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I have a fundamental disagreement and I think most Republicans and most Americans do, that we shouldn't be allowing billions of dollars to go to nations that hate us to go to Cuba, to go to Iran and to let them use those billions of dollars to try to murder us.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: BASH
text: Thank you Senator Cruz.

speaker: BASH
text: Mr. Trump.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Well, if Ted was listening, he would have heard me say something very similar.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I said we would not do the deal unless it was going to be a very good deal for us.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think I said it loud and I think I said it very clear.

speaker: TRUMP
text: And I think after 50 years, and I have many friends, I own many properties in Miami, many, many, and I have many people that know and they feel exactly the way I do, make a deal, it would be great, but it's got to be a great deal for the United States, not a bad deal for the United States.

speaker: TRUMP
text: As far as Iran is concerned, I would have never made that deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: That is one of the worst deals ever, ever made by this country.

speaker: TRUMP
text: It is a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So for Ted to say I agree with this deal, I mean, it's a staple in my speeches that that may he worst single deal I've ever seen negotiated.

speaker: TRUMP
text: So don't try to put it on me like it's wonderful, like I love it.

speaker: BASH
text: Senator Cruz, your response?

speaker: CRUZ
text: Well, look.

speaker: CRUZ
text: I'll point out first of all it is a matter of public record that Donald supported John Kerry in 2004 over George W. Bush, and he supported Hillary Clinton, gave her two checks in a presidential campaign in 2008.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And indeed, once she was secretary of State, he described her as one of the greatest secretaries of State in industry.

speaker: CRUZ
text: And, you know, the point on the Iran deal, his answer to everything is if only if someone smarter were in government, things would be better.

speaker: CRUZ
text: No.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We don't just need smarter people in government.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We need leaders that are protecting American interests.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: CRUZ
text: And when it comes to Iran, Donald has said he would leave the agreement in place and try to renegotiate it, giving the Ayatollah Khomeini over $100 billion.

speaker: CRUZ
text: That reflects you do not understand the radical Islam terrorist that is the Ayatollah that wants to murder us.

speaker: CRUZ
text: We need a commander in chief that understands our enemies...

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (BELL RINGS)

speaker: CRUZ
text: ... understands and doesn't give them billions of dollars to threaten our safety and security.

speaker: SYSTEM
text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: TRUMP
text: I was against the giving of the money at all cost.

speaker: TRUMP
text: I said don't negotiate at all until you get the prisoners back.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If the prisoners don't come back early - three years ago.

speaker: TRUMP
text: One of the longest negotiations I've ever seen, by the way.

speaker: TRUMP
text: If they don't come back early, I was saying don't negotiate.

speaker: TRUMP
text: They come back early.

speaker: TRUMP
text: What you do is you take it back and you say, either give us the prisoners or we double up the sanctions.

speaker: TRUMP
text: What we should have done is doubled up the sanctions and made a much better deal.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Cause that deal is a disaster.

speaker: TRUMP
text: Ted, the money is largely gone because of incompetent and very, very poor negotiators.

speaker: TRUMP
text: But that money, the $150 billion, is largely gone and already spent everywhere but the United States.

speaker: BASH
text: Thank you Mr. Trump.

speaker: BASH
text: Let's refocus this back on Cuba.

text: Governor Kasich, a pair of entrepreneurs from Alabama and North Carolina have just received approval to build the first U.S. factory in Cuba, making tractor for small farms.

text: If you were elected would you encourage more U.S. companies to do business like that in Cuba?

speaker: KASICH
text: Listen, I think the problem with the administration, if you talk to our friends around the world, they say what is America doing?

speaker: KASICH
text: You know, you don't support us, we can't figure out where you are.

text: You won't arm the freedom fighters in Ukraine, we let the Russians trump up some excuse in the business of Russian-speaking people.

text: You walked away from it.

speaker: KASICH
text: You refused to fund the Syrian rebels, you undercut Egypt and we ended up with the Muslim brotherhood for awhile.

speaker: KASICH
text: And then we turn our back on Netanyahu when he comes to Congress to talk about his concerns of the Iranian deal.

speaker: KASICH
text: Look, I know in human nature sometimes there's a sense that you make better with your enemies than you do with your friends.

speaker: KASICH
text: And you know what happens when you do that?

speaker: KASICH
text: You make a terrible mistake.

speaker: KASICH
text: You need to support your friends, you need to hold your enemies out here...

speaker: KASICH

speaker: TAPPER
text: While we're discussing the issues of importance to Floridians, I reached out to the Republican mayor of Miami, Tomas Regalado, to find out what he wanted to hear from you this evening.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Mayor Regalado told me, quote, "Climate change means rising ocean levels, which in south Florida means flooding downtown and in our neighborhoods. It's an every day reality in our city. Will you, as president acknowledge the reality of the scientific consensus about climate change and as president, will you pledge to do something about it?"

speaker: TAPPER
text: Unquote.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Senator Rubio, the Miami mayor has endorsed you.

speaker: TAPPER
text: Will you honor his request for a pledge and acknowledge the reality of the scientific consensus of climate change and pledge to do something about it?

text: Well, sure if the climate is changing and one of the reasons is because the climate has always been changing.

text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RUBIO
text: There's never been a time when the climate has not changed.

speaker: RUBIO

text: So on the issue of flooding in Miami, it's caused by two things.

speaker: RUBIO
text: Number one, south Florida is largely built on land that was once a swamp.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And number two, because if there is higher sea levels or whatever it may be happening, we do need to deal with that through mitigation.

speaker: RUBIO
text: And I have long supported mitigation efforts.

speaker: RUBIO
text: But as far as a law that we can pass in Washington to change the weather, there's no such thing.

text: (APPLAUSE)

speaker: RUBIO
text: Americans are going to pay the price of that.

speaker: RUBIO

speaker: RUBIO

text: The great thing about politics, the reason why we watch it is because what's true today is not necessarily true tomorrow.

speaker: KASICH
text: So let's not get ahead of ourselves.

speaker: KASICH
text: If you got an 86, you got a B.

speaker: KASICH
text: Because everybody else had an 84 didn't mean you got an A.

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH
text: And frankly, I don't know if we're going to get a convention like that.

speaker: KASICH
text: But if we do, I was at one in 1976 as a wee lad and supported Ronald Reagan and actually worked directly with him.

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH
text: But let's not get ahead of ourselves.

speaker: KASICH

speaker: KASICH
